PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 1.45 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh), in his capacity as Minister Assisting the Minister for Trade and Resources, will leave Australia today to lead the Australian delegation at the inaugural meeting of the Australia-Iraq Joint Commission in Iraq and to attend the opening of the Australian trade display in Saudi Arabia. The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) will act as Minister for Housing and Construction until Mr McVeigh returns.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Does advice to the right honourable gentleman suggest that interest rates have peaked? If not, will he give an assurance that housing interest rates will be insulated from upward pressures on interest rates coming mainly from the professional money market? Will he specifically assure the Parliament that a further rise in home loan interest rates will not be postponed merely beyond the Lowe by-election and Victorian State election, just as interest rate rises were held back in late 1980 until after the Federal and Queensland elections?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Government has made it quite plain that it is giving a good deal of attention to this particular problem. Both the Treasurer and I in recent days have sought to point out that the arrangements that have served Australia well over about 30 years in encouraging home ownership and in lifting home ownership from around 50 per cent to 70 per cent of the Australian community are not acting as effectively today as they have, largely because of higher interest rates. I think we have also both given an indication that, because of the world environment, of which we are a part, and because of policies in other countries, it is unlikely that Australia will return to the economic environment of the 1950s and 1960s and therefore that the circumstances are changed.

ANSWER.PARA: What we need to do is to examine very carefully policies related to housing which are designed to encourage home ownership. We have sought to point out that there are two basic problems: Firstly, how to achieve adequate money flows so that sufficient loans can be made on reasonable terms; and, secondly, how to make sure that those loans are provided at a price that people can afford. The objective of home ownership is one that Liberal governments have pursued assiduously over a long period. It is my firm belief that they would want to continue doing so. The circumstances are quite different today.

As a result of last week's Premiers Conference, one of the things that we have asked the States to do at their meeting tomorrow is to see what suggestions they have for encouraging greater capital flows through permanent building societies and State savings banks which come within their province and are under their control. It will be interesting to see what views the States have in relation to that. It is very easy to come to the view that subsidies ought to be provided to lower the cost of housing loans. But unless consequential steps are taken to make sure that the capital for lending for housing is also increased the subsidy might only add further costs to the loan or money that is already there, thus driving up the cost of that money and providing no net benefit to the home builder or home purchaser. Therefore, we are seeking to have the States' views on these particular matters.

It is also relevant to try to get their views on the impact of the recommendations of the Commission of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System as they affect State instrumentalities, such as the building societies and State savings banks - institutions that come within State law. I am not too sure that the States have given too much attention to the impact of those recommendations on their own authorities. I hope this will be addressed in their meeting that is being held, as I understand it, tomorrow. Obviously, their views will be taken into account.

I think it ought to be pointed out that on the one hand the honourable gentleman asked that, if there were to be a change in interest rates for home loans, that not be delayed and on the other hand I think he asked that market forces be allowed to operate. That would seem to be consistent with the Campbell report. No doubt he is aware that many home interest rates are controlled at present. He would also be aware, I suppose, that his own leader does not support the thrust of his question because he advocates the control of all interest rates. The honourable gentleman cannot have it both ways; he cannot ask us to respond to market pressures in this area and at the same time support his own leader who suggests that there should be no market pressures at all in this area .

The final point I make is that those who have mortgages or home loans or who want to have home loans should discount totally the vastly irresponsible and unreasonable scare tactics of the Premier of New South Wales who suggested that interest for home loans would go to 18 per cent. The only thing that could give any validity to that is if Mr Wran were going to lift the interest rates of the New South Wales permanent building societies or savings banks to 18 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs seen reports that the Government intends to terminate a third of the projects operating under the Community Youth Support Scheme? In complimenting the Minister for his role in having CYSS continued under new guidelines, I ask him whether he can inform the House whether the Government contemplates such a course. I also ask the Minister whether he can advise the House of when an announcement will be made on those projects which will receive funds and those which will not receive funds under these recently announced guidelines.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see a statement of the nature to which the honourable member referred; in fact a Press release issued last night by the honourable member for Wills. This was disappointing in view of the lecture we had on how this was a non-political issue and how when the Parliament was sitting matters relating to the Community Youth Support Scheme should be raised in the Parliament and not be the subject of Press releases. However, the statement to which the honourable member for Cook referred accused the Government of a lack of sincerity in this matter and announced to the world in a scare-mongering fashion that the Government was about to terminate one-third of the Community Youth Support Scheme projects.

ANSWER.PARA: In fact, the true situation is that the Government has been taking advice from the State advisory committees and from its own officials on this matter and had decided, in fact, before the honourable member for Wills issued his scandal- mongering statement, to continue funding the projects under this scheme to a substantial extent. In fact, some 95 per cent of the projects will receive additional and increased funds and travelling allowances for the participants until the end of June when, of course, the new system comes into operation. The situation is that of the 271 projects currently in existence the Government will continue funds for 260. As I have said, the appropriation for each of the projects will be increased to the extent of about 10 per cent in most cases and a further 5 per cent for the travelling allowances of the participants. It remains for me to say that if the honourable member for Wills had been consistent with his protestations of a non-partisan attitude on this matter and had had the decency to raise the matter with me instead of issuing a Press statement, I would have been able to inform him of these facts.

Finally, may I say that it is now a matter for the project officers and the committees to respond to the confidence that the Government has now placed in them to ensure that this system continues to work well and that the projects serve the real needs of young unemployed people in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to his suggestion to the Premiers last week that they should consider controlling cash management trusts in order to increase funds available for housing. In view of his qualification yesterday that he was not suggesting that the States use legislative controls, how does he intend that the States should control cash management trusts? Is it a fact that the States cannot implement meaningful controls over cash management trusts? Is it also a fact that the most effective means of controlling the activities of such trusts and redirecting funds for housing is for the Commonwealth immediately to proclaim Part IV of the Financial Corporations Act, which gives the Commonwealth wide- ranging powers to control all financial institutions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret to say that the honourable gentleman has been inadequately advised. Even if Part IV of the Financial Corporations Act were proclaimed, it would not give the Commonwealth control over cash management trusts which are established under State law. The point in mentioning cash management trusts at the Premiers Conference last week was to emphasise to the Premiers the point that changes in the capital markets had pulled money away from savings banks and permanent buildings societies and to make the point that some of this had occurred not in relation to matters that are within the legislative power of the Commonwealth but in relation to matters which are very firmly within the legislative power of the States. It was necessary, indeed, to make the point that the States have responsibilities in these areas.

ANSWER.PARA: There are organisations established under State law-the permanent building societies, again, and the State savings banks-which are affected by State decisions. In some States they are given some capacity to compete; in other States they are fairly rigidly controlled. But if there is to be a genuine attempt by governments to achieve a greater flow of capital for housing, so that the very high home ownership ratio in Australia can be maintained, quite plainly the States have some role in that. I believe the very fact that the Victorian Premier has called a meeting of Premiers-even though I understand that Mr Wran will not be present-is recognition of the fact that the States have a very real role. I hope that they will give us some advice as to how they believe greater funds can be attracted into their own particular institutions for house lending purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industry, relates to the plant variety rights legislation. What has transpired since the Minister met with the Australian Agricultural Council recently, when it was reported that certain States, namely, I think, New South Wales and Tasmania, claimed that he had overruled the Council and that they required more time for consideration of the proposed legislation? Has the Minister considered any changes to the legislation, perhaps in relation to merit assessment along the lines already applicable in relation to the Australian Herbage Plant Cultivars Register? When may we anticipate that this legislation will come before the House?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I read with some interest claims made by the New South Wales Minister for Agriculture and Fisheries that I had overriden the wishes of the Agricultural Council in respect of a decision that I announced at the Agricultural Council meeting to proceed with the plant variety rights policy and program. At an Agricultural Council meeting some six months ago, I indicated to the Council that, if there were not agreement amongst the States, I would take the views of the States into account in coming to a decision. At the Agricultural Council meeting in Adelaide the other day it became clear that the great majority of the States wanted to proceed with the legislation. South Australia, Victoria, Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory were in favour of it. Tasmania gave long ideological reasons-they were mostly party political-why it was not in favour and New South Wales sat on the fence. The New South Wales Minister must be feeling very sore where he sits because he squirmed around so much trying to find reasons why he could not be in favour of it. He finally came to a conclusion, after I had announced that in light of the views taken by the States I would proceed with the legislation in the House and arbitrate the issue as I said I would do. The New South Wales Minister promptly jumped on what he likes to think is a bandwagon of public appeal. He said that I was overriding the views of the Agricultural Council. The fact is that the great majority of the States wish to proceed, and as far as I am aware there is a unanimous view amongst industry organisations that the legislation ought to proceed. Even State organisations such as the Tasmania Farmers and Graziers Co- operative Society Ltd sent me a telex pointing out that the Tasmanian Minister was not expressing its view accurately if he opposed the scheme. In view of the almost unanimous approach taken by these people, I decided that the Bill ought to proceed.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the latter part of the honourable member's question, there will not be merit testing. It has never been thought that there should be. The honourable member also asked about any amendments. Having regard to the fact that Tasmania and New South Wales have said that they now oppose the scheme-I think they are using the words 'in its present form' but I am not sure what they mean by that- I have written them a letter and invited them to send amendments to me so that we may consider them on the floor of the House during debate on the Bill. When the Bill will come into the House is a matter for the Leader of the House. I will try to get an accurate answer to that part of the question for the honourable member.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to his statement in Sydney on 22 February that 'there is no proposal to change housing interest rates and I know of no proposal that there should be'. In light of that statement and reports to the contrary, I ask the Prime Minister: Have the banks applied to the Government for an increase in the controlled interest rate on home mortgages and small overdrafts? If so, by what amount have the banks requested that these interest rates be lifted? When does the Government intend to reply to the banks' request?
—The statement that I made in Sydney is accurate so far as I know, within my knowledge.

—I refer the Minister for Transport to his news release last Friday concerning a top structure review of his Department. How extensive has this review been? Can the Minister give further details of the resulting proposal to create a discrete office of civil aviation within his Department? How meaningful is this proposal and what will be the role of the office? Finally, who will head the office and what will his or her responsibilities be?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —A top management review of the Department of Transport by the Public Service Board has been in progress for the last 18 months and is now nearing its conclusion. At a recent meeting of the Aviation Industry Advisory Council I raised the question of a restructure of the Department with representatives of the aviation industry. They decided to set up a small sub-committee to examine the current structure and to make some input to the discussion that has been taking place within the Department and between the Secretary and myself. We have taken note of the views of the aviation industry, and those views have been taken up by the Secretary to the Department in discussions with the Public Service Board. A firm proposal has been put to the Public Service Board for the establishment of a discrete office of civil aviation which will cover the policy and operational aspects of aviation. It will be headed by a senior officer of the Second Division of the Public Service. It is intended that that officer will have direct access to the Minister but will be responsible to the Secretary to the Department, who has the statutory responsibility for aviation safety.

ANSWER.PARA: The Secretary has also placed before the Public Service Board other proposals relating to surface transport administration in the Department. It is intended that it should also be an office of surface transport administration. A number of divisions will be amalgamated in the course of this review. I would expect the Public Service Board to be in a position to make some announcement about this in the very near future. I know that there will be further discussions between the Secretary to the Department of Transport and the Chairman of the Public Service Board early next week. I hope we will then be in a position to make firm announcements as to how the office of civil aviation will operate. Of course, the position of the senior officer will have to be advertised in accordance with the normal procedures of the Public Service Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that an overall increase of $20 a week in home loan repayments has been inflicted on home buyers in the past two years? Is it also a fact that Commonwealth expenditure on housing has been cut by a massive 70 per cent under this Government? Will the Government give immediate priority to Australians' desire to own their own home?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it would be possible to make an overall judgment about the increased repayments as a result of interest rate changes because it depends on the circumstances of each borrower, the time at which a borrower took out the loan and, obviously, the amount of the loan. There are people who have taken out a loan in the recent period-maybe in the last two or three years-and who could be in a worse position. But a person who took out a loan five or six years ago and made the normal repayments in the period since is probably in a better position than he would have been when he originally took out the loan. So the areas of greatest difficulty are probably those concerning people who have just taken out a loan in recent times or those who are not able to afford a loan at the current cost.

ANSWER.PARA: When one is looking at the support that the Commonwealth provides for housing it is necessary to look not only at the direct payments to the States under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement but also at the $125m provided this year and the significantly greater amount that we will be providing next year in support for single income pensioners who pay rent and who have very little other income. That is obviously very real support for individuals who would obviously qualify, in most people's minds, for welfare housing. The payment is made direct to the individual and it is money laid out, I believe, under the general heading of welfare housing. In addition to this, the homes savings grants and the support for defence service homes are also funds that the Commonwealth has laid out in a very substantial manner in general support for housing. Subject to correction, I believe that the Commonwealth's budgetary outlays for housing in the last Budget increased by about 17 per cent, which is a significant increase in real terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Primary Industry: What stage has been reached in negotiations to sell the Australian Wool Testing Authority? Is it correctly reported in this morning's Press that it will be a condition of sale that testing fees will rise by no more than 4 per cent and that any prospective buyer would be exempt from paying income tax? If these reports are correct, what is the rationale for selling the Wool Testing Authority and so depriving the Australian Wool Corporation of a profitable source of income?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an interesting question.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very interesting response from the Opposition. The Opposition, of course, is so free-enterprise minded that as long as the socialists win all the way down the track it does not care.
—Look at the rural socialists. You do better than anyone else.

—I thank the honourable gentleman very much. I will take that as a compliment. The Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions that looked at this matter determined that there was an absolute prospect for the Australian Wool Testing Authority to carry out its function if it operated in a private sector way instead of as a Commonwealth statutory organisation. The upshot of it is that at some peak employment periods of the year there will be some 600 fewer Commonwealth public servants on the payroll of the Commonwealth Public Service. People have lost track of the fact that the AWTA is a statutory authority of this Parliament. It is a Commonwealth body set up under the Wool Industry Act. All its facilities and employees are owned and controlled by the Australian Wool Corporation which is also a statutory authority set up by this Parliament. Transferring this organisation to the private sector removes one of the quasi- autonomous national government organisations about which I have heard members of the Opposition and Senate committees complaining. It can carry out its function with all the integrity and skills that presently apply. I do not think the wool industry will even know that there has been a transfer as far as the matter of its integrity is concerned. It will maintain its international reputation and do its job just as well-a very successful operation, even if I say so myself.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. Will the 260 projects referred to by the Minister in his earlier answer be sufficiently funded to enable them to operate at their previous levels of activity? Will the continuing funding of the Community Youth Support Scheme projects during 1981-82 require a redirection of funds from departmental programs or activities? If so, which programs and activities will be affected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker-Mr Speaker, I must apologise. I have no intention of demoting you. In answer to the honourable gentleman's question, which was so carefully written out for him by his colleague, the honourable member for Wills, in the first place the projects will receive-in the case of virtually all of them-not the present sum which is appropriated for them but an increased amount, as I have already said. A handful of projects which are very large will receive at least the present amount which is payable to them without any increase.

ANSWER.PARA: I think that is quite reasonable and consistent with the new guidelines. The answer to the second part of the honourable member's question is that, by judicious and careful analysis of programs, I now have available money that may be spent on CYSS which I understand everyone seems to say is so deserving of a very high priority. We are dispensing that money accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Trade and Resources whether it is a fact that Japan is concerned about our unreliable shipping of steaming coal. Is this important market under threat from South Africa, Canada, the United States of America and China? What steps can be taken to ensure reliable shipping to this important area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fair enough to say that the Japanese are not only concerned about the shipping of steaming coal but also about the reliability of our shipping of coking coal. Our coal export performance during 1981 was not something to be admired. We had tremendous hold-ups along the waterfronts and this irritated the Japanese immensely. If one is responsible for keeping a large power station or a steel works operating in Japan, one cannot be put to the vagaries of when supplies are likely to arrive. One has to have a guaranteed source of supply and know that it will arrive regularly. I do know that as a result of our performance last year the Japanese are giving greater attention to getting their coking coal from places such as Canada and the United States of America. They are also certainly looking around to see what other sources of steaming coal there are. In the interests of developing our coal industry, be it steaming or coking coal, I hope that the unions that have caused so much of this trouble-in many cases as a result only of demarcation disputes between the unions-might realise the damage that they are doing to those industries that employ a lot of people and also to Australia's reputation as a trader. Our balance of payments situation is not comfortable. We need to maintain a high level of exports. It is in the overall interest of the nation and of our fellow Australians. I hope the people who are causing the troubles will recognise that.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Treasurer. He will recall the answer of the Prime Minister to a question a few minutes ago from the honourable member for Gellibrand in relation to whether there had been any proposal before the Government for a change in interest rates. He will recall the Prime Minister's denial that there is or has been any such proposal before the Government. Is the Treasurer aware that the Executive Director of the Australian Bankers Association, Mr R. Cameron, publicly declared on the night of 3 February that the private banks had in fact proposed to the Government in the preceding fortnight that there should be an increase in home interest rates? Is that statement correct?

QUESTION.PARA: The honourable member continuing to ask his question-

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. Before I call the Treasurer I indicate to him that I will permit as in order the first part of the question. I rule the second part of the question out of order. It is not appropriate in this House to ask any member to answer in relation to private matters. The Cabinet is a private matter and the honourable gentleman cannot be questioned about it in the chamber.

—I take a point of order. Mr Speaker, how can you possibly declare that it is a private matter when it is public record? Ministers give briefings to reputable journalists as to what is taking place in the Cabinet.

—The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. If the honourable gentleman wishes to base his question on a newspaper report, he must vouch for the accuracy of it. In fact his question was put in terms of: Is it accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the whole of the four years that I have been Treasurer, the Executive Director of the Australian Bankers Association has been regularly-at least on a monthly basis-calling for the complete decontrol of interest rates. It is nothing new or out of the ordinary for Mr Cameron to be quoted as saying that he believes that all interest rates should be decontrolled.
—That's not it at all.

—If the excitable gentleman opposite will allow me, I will continue. Of course, the consequence of that is that, in respect of those interest rates that are controlled, some variation could occur. Whether, of course, the average cost of money would go up is another matter.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member for Gellibrand, as I recall it, asked the Prime Minister whether a particular request from the banks for an increase had been received. That was my understanding of what the honourable gentleman asked. Such a request , if it had been made, would normally not have been conveyed to the Prime Minister nor to me but to the Reserve Bank of Australia which administers controls under the Banking Act and approves variations in the ceiling after consultation with me on behalf of the Government. To the best of my recollection no specific request for a particular variation has been made to the Reserve Bank in recent times. I shall, of course, check that and inform the House if my recollection is faulty. But I can simply confirm that in no way would such a request have been made to the Prime Minister and as a consequence his answer to the honourable member for Gellibrand was in all respects completely accurate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Communications aware that the public face-to-face telephone service at the Melbourne General Post Office will close as from next Saturday? Is he also aware that the service renders a vital aid to thousands of consumers of the Telecom network including migrants, tourists and handicapped people who in some cases cannot see or have difficulty in handling telephone equipment? Is he also aware that this will be the only major GPO throughout Australia that does not have such a service? In light of the fact that only 10 days' notice was given before closure is to be effected, will he assure the House that he will take steps to prevent the closure on Saturday? Will he take whatever steps are open to him to ensure that that vital service continues to be made available to the people I have mentioned?

—I am not aware of the allegations to which the honourable member refers. I shall therefore treat the question as being on notice and furnish the honourable member with a reply as expeditiously as possible.

—Is the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware that there were 917 small business bankruptcies in Victoria for the financial year ended June 1980? Is he also aware that this represents a jump of 54 per cent on the previous year 's figures? Is it a fact that because of his Government's policies he has created the highest number of bankruptcies of small businesses ever recorded in Australia? Finally, what are he and his Government doing to stop the disastrous plight of small businesses in general and in Victoria in particular?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the question from the honourable gentleman because my information is that the preliminary indications are that bankruptcies in 1980 -81 will show the lowest rate of increase for some years. At the same time, to put the question in perspective, the House should be aware that new business formations continue to increase at a very satisfactory rate. The honourable gentleman refers specifically to Victoria. I inform him that actual new business registrations in Victoria in 1980-81 were 31,000, an average of around 125 per working day. This is a 6 per cent increase on 1979-80 when 29,000 new businesses were registered compared with 688 business bankruptcies. I might also say that almost 19,100 new companies were incorporated in Victoria in 1980-81 and that, for the information of the honourable gentleman, happens to be 30 per cent higher than four years ago.

ANSWER.PARA: Starting a new business, of course, is no sinecure. It is a fact of life that some businesses will not make the grade. The important point to be made in response to the honourable gentleman is that only a small proportion of Australia's small business owners wind up bankrupt. On the basis of information provided to me by my Department and the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, the odds against that happening appear to be lengthening. The fact of the matter is that at the present time that is an example of a strong Australian economy. It is an indication of the success of our fiscal and monetary policies. There is no doubt that at the present time more Australians are finding it worthwhile to go into business for themselves and more are making a success of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs consider establishing a migration office in Salisbury, Zimbabwe? Is he aware of the difficulties currently being experienced by Europeans living in that country and wishing to migrate to Australia because of both the monetary restrictions imposed by the Zimbabwe Government and the need for such prospective migrants to deal through and travel to South Africa for interviews?

—From time to time the Government has looked at the relevance of having a migration office in Zimbabwe. So far we have not thought it appropriate to do so, for several reasons. First of all, the principal barrier to migration is the foreign exchange limitation imposed by the Zimbabwe Government, about which we can do nothing. In fact, access to Pretoria is quite easy, infinitely easier than is access to, say, Damascus from Beirut and in other parts of the world that have to put up with a similar situation. We simply cannot maintain migration offices all around the world. So far persons in Zimbabwe seeking to migrate have had no difficulty of which I am aware in going to Pretoria. They do have the problem of deciding whether to leave without their assets if they are accepted for migration. If the honourable member is aware of any cases of people who have had difficulty I would be pleased to look into them. An interview can be conducted by Department of Foreign Affairs officials in the Australian Embassy in Salisbury. That frequently is done.

—I ask the Treasurer: Is it a fact that the Foreign Investment Review Board has provided information to the effect that heavy calls made by foreign controlled enterprises on the Australian capital market have implications for Australian controlled enterprises which are competing in the market? Is it a fact that the relevant table shows that foreign controlled enterprises have increased their borrowings from approximately $2 billion in 1975 to $7.7 billion in 1979 and that in 1979 Australian lenders contributed 73 per cent of all funds used by foreign companies in this country? Does that mean that the Australian capital market is short of funds because of funds now going to foreign controlled enterprises? Does that not mean higher interest rates and less funds being available for housing?

—I accept as accurate the figures cited by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. They do not mean that the Australian capital market is short of funds. What they mean is that if we are to have the rate of growth in the Australian economy that I understand members of the Australian Labor Party in their more rational moments also support we must have capital from abroad. As a nation we simply do not save enough and we do not have enough capacity amongst Australian corporations to provide the sort of economic growth and the sort of economic development that I understand it to be the desire of the Australian community to have. We cannot, on the one hand, run a foreign investment policy- an economic policy that depends upon the contribution by foreigners to the development of this country-and, on the other hand, deny those contributors access to loan funds from our capital market and expect them to stay here. To claim that it is possible to do that is an absolute absurdity; it does not make any sense.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to ask a supplementary question.
—I call the honourable member for Bowman.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Has the downturn in international airline traffic had any significant effect on the number of overseas visitors coming to Australia? Is the Minister still confident that $1 billion will be spent by visitors to this country this year? Has the downturn affected the massive expansion of hotel building programs throughout the Commonwealth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman is certainly correct in referring to the downturn which has taken place in recent years in the international tourist industry. That is having some effect upon the number of visitor arrivals in Australia. Having said that, I should certainly emphasise to the House that the increase in the number of visitor arrivals in recent years and those we expect during the current calendar year will see the arrival of one millon visitors to Australia. At the same time I put on the record that our estimate is that they will spend approximately $1 billion. Despite the downturn in international tourist flows, confidence in the industry remains very strong indeed. This, I think, is very starkly reflected in the tremendous boom which has taken place recently in planned tourist accommodation. According to the latest survey by the Cordell group, the value of projects in this area stood at some $1.5 billion in September 1981. That happens to be an increase of 11 1/2 per cent over the June 1981 total. At the same time, accommodation takings have increased strongly. For hotels, motels and caravan parks they were 20 per cent higher in the September 1981 quarter than they were a year earlier. But, for these prospects to continue to be assured, I would certainly remind the House of the need for a stable cost structure in the industry and the need for stability in the industry's industrial relations pattern. This has been an enormous problem for entrepreneurs in the Australian tourist industry during the past year or two. I believe it is important that both employers and, certainly, the trade unions recognise the need for stability in the industrial relations area because if there is one thing that can certainly interrupt the flow of tourist traffic to Australia it is the uncertainty and unpredictability caused by overseas visitors not being absolutely sure that they can arrive on time and leave according to their holiday itinerary.
—Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. There is a provision under the Standing Orders for supplementary questions. It is Standing Order 151. It assuredly would have been included in the Standing Orders for the purpose of being applied at least from time to time. I might point out that since you have been the Speaker I can remember no occasion when you have allowed a supplementary question to be asked. TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to inform the House of decisions I have taken not to accept two recommendations of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to revoke deportation orders against Mr Luigi Pochi and Mr Vincenzo Barbaro. I do so because of the significance for public administration of a decision to reject a recommendation of the Tribunal. The Tribunal represents a method of external review which allows people to challenge a wide range of decisions on their merits made by public servants and Ministers alike, thus affording a high level of protection of individual rights. I believe there are few countries in the world which allow people, convicted of a criminal offence, such a wide ranging review of deportation before a person of the calibre of an Australian Federal Court Judge.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe Ministers ought rarely to reject recommendations after such a review, but for the reasons which I will outline, I feel obliged to do so in these two cases. My predecessor signed deportation orders against Mr Pochi and Mr Barbaro following their convictions for supplying Indian hemp. They were both charged with this offence after they were each found by police on huge marihuana plantations in New South Wales. Both men applied to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for review of my predecessor's decisions to deport them. In each case the Tribunal recommended revocation of the deportation orders. Because Mr Justice Brennan formulated principles in the Pochi case which were seen to have serious implications for following cases, my predecessor, acting on legal advice , appealed to the Federal Court. The decision of the Federal Court did not fully resolve the issues and on the basis of legal advice I sought leave to appeal to the High Court.

The High Court refused special leave to appeal. It did so on the ground that its decision in the case would not be binding on the Minister. Since the Minister is not bound to give effect to a recommendation by the Tribunal to revoke a deportation order, he is therefore left with the ultimate responsibility to determine whether it is in the public interest that a criminal be deported. In doing so, he must, of course, take into account the recommendation of the Tribunal. The High Court said that the Minister is not required to accept as correct any views as to the facts or as to the weight of evidentiary material expressed by the Tribunal. Thus it is clear that the Minister is entitled to make up his own mind as to the weight he gives to the material before him and that he may take into account and make his decision on the basis of matters which the Tribunal did not think to be sufficiently established before it.

Following the handing down of the High Court's reasons, I called for a detailed briefing on the cases of Mr Pochi and Mr Barbaro. In relation to Mr Pochi, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal recommended revocation of the deportation order on several grounds. The main ground was that Mr Justice Brennan considered that the material before him did not warrant a positive finding that Mr Pochi was involved in commerce in marihuana. On this basis Mr Justice Brennan concluded that the hardship to the Pochi family which would arise as a result of deportation outweighed the benefits to be gained by the community from deportation.

I believe however that my predecessor's decision to deport Mr Pochi was vindicated by the report of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, known as the Woodward report. This report was not available at the time the Administrative Appeals Tribunal reviewed my predecessor's decision. In fact since that report was published the Tribunal has in two cases referred to findings in it in the course of upholding a decision to deport.

In my view, the findings of the Woodward report are very pertinent to the question of whether Mr Pochi should be allowed to remain in Australia and consequently, it is my duty as responsible Minister to take those findings into account. In his report Justice Woodward concluded that: Mr Pochi was a member of a secret Calabrian criminal organisation; he was a Canberra principal of that organisation; the organisation was directly responsible for a large quantity of marihuana cultivation and distribution; several of Mrs Pochi's relatives were also members of the organisation; the growing of the marihuana for the organisation was supervised from Griffith principally by Mr Pochi's brother-in- law and business partner, Mr Antonio Sergi; the distribution and marketing of the drug on behalf of the organisation was supervised principally by Mr Pochi's other business partner, Mr Robert Trimboli; the organisation was responsible for the disappearance and murder of Donald Bruce Mackay.

What the Woodward report had to say about several of Mrs Pochi's relatives is relevant both to the risk of Mr Pochi's further involvement in the organisation and to the impact upon her of his deportation. The Woodward Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking revealed that Mr and Mrs Pochi had acquired assets far in excess of their legitimate income. The Royal Commission and indeed the Tribunal itself did not accept the Pochis' explanation as to how they acquired those assets.

I believe that any decision to deport a person is one which cannot be taken lightly. This is particularly so when the case concerns a person who has resided in Australia for many years. In such cases I need to take special care to satisfy myself that deportation is justified. Mr Pochi was advised that I intended to reconsider the question of his deportation in the light of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal's recommendation in his case and the findings of the Woodward report. Mr and Mrs Pochi were given an opportunity to reply in writing and to present his case to me in person. In particular, they were invited to comment upon the findings of the Woodward report. Nothing which was put to me by or on behalf of the Pochis qualified-in my view-the findings of the Woodward Report. Accordingly I have concluded that although the hardship to Mr Pochi and his family as a result of deportation would be substantial, I am satisfied that, in view of his involvement in such an insidious organisation, his deportation is in the best interests of Australia.

In the case of Mr Vincenzo Barbaro, Mr Justice Fisher was satisfied that his involvement in the operation of the marihuana plantation where he was working at the time of his arrest was probably that of a farm labourer. Mr Justice Fisher stated that if Mr Barbaro's involvement was more than that of a farm labourer the scales would be weighted heavily in favour of deportation. The Woodward report concluded that Mr Barbaro was a member of the same organisation as Mr Pochi. Mr Justice Fisher referred to the Woodward report but considered that, on the evidence before him, he should not proceed on the basis that Mr Barbaro was involved as 'a trusted member of the Griffith organisation'. Having looked both at the Woodward report and at the findings of facts made by the Tribunal, I find myself persuaded that the involvement of Mr Barbaro was much more than that of a farm labourer. As I have said, it is clear from the High Court decision that I am entitled to make up my own mind as to the weight I place on the findings of the Woodward report, and that I am entitled to differ from the Tribunal. Because of his membership of the organisation and the nature of its activities I believe that a decision allowing Mr Barbaro to stay would be against the Australian public interest.

Deportation is never ordered as a punishment and should not be accepted as a second punishment. Its purpose is to remove from the community persons who have demonstrated by their conduct that they are unacceptable to the overwhelming majority of Australians. I firmly believe that Mr Barbaro and particularly Mr Pochi present a risk to the Australian public.

I wish to make it clear that I do not lightly disregard the recommendations of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. There have been 30 cases considered by the Tribunal where it has been recommended that a deportation order be revoked. Of these, only three recommendations, including those concerning Mr Pochi and Mr Barbaro, have not been accepted. In the third case, deportation did not eventuate because the person concerned was killed in an accident within a few days of my decision to reject the Tribunal's recommendation.

I regard the last few years as being an important learning process for all concerned including the members of the Tribunal and me. The review process by the Tribunal has been of specific benefit in criminal deportation cases as it has required my Department to undertake more searching investigations before recommending deportation. This has resulted in greater protection to the individuals affected by deportation.

I have noted several comments made by the Tribunal on the Government's policy relating to the deportation of persons convicted of criminal offences. As a result, I believe that the policy is possibly in need of some modification. I have requested my Department to examine the policy in the light of the Tribunal' s comments and to report to me. Any changes to the policy that might be approved by the Government relating to the deportation of persons convicted of criminal offences will be announced as soon as possible. The changes I contemplate would have no relevance to cases such as those of Messrs Pochi and Barbaro.
The decisions regarding Messrs Pochi and Barbaro have been difficult ones to make. I believe however that in the interests of the Australian community, no other proper course of action is open to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said a few moments ago, the Opposition treats this matter with the utmost seriousness. SPEECH.PARA: These two men, if they are deported, will be the first to be subjected to this type of decision. As the Minister so rightly points out, we have to take seriously the views of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. We on this side of the House do not disagree with the Minister's having the ultimate responsibility for making decisions in these cases. We do not quarrel with that. We do quarrel with the Government's ignoring what the Administrative Appeals Tribunal had to say in both of these cases. By and large we would agree with the statement made by the Minister in regard to the process of deportation, which was released to the Press on 31 January 1980. He spent some time in saying that the national interest must be considered when we are talking about the deportation of people from this country.

The Minister's statement says, and quite correctly, that the two people are to be deported following their convictions for 'supplying Indian hemp'. Supplying is a misnomer for the offences which they committed. As I understand it, ' supplying' embraces a range of offences which may have been covered by the term. In the literal sense, they were not supplying Indian hemp. They were both found on projects where Indian hemp was being grown. It is a little unfortunate also that both men have been linked in this one statement. They were not on the same property. They do not come from the same area. As I understand it, they are not related. But they are being lumped together today in this statement.

The fact that they have been convicted, and that the penalties have been carried out in Australia-Mr Pochi has served one year in an Australian prison and Mr Barbaro has served two years-means that, as far as Australian civil law is concerned, they have served the sentences for which they were convicted for the offences which they carried out. As I said earlier, deportation is the ultimate in the penalties that can be imposed on anyone. In this country 1.3 million people who are eligible for citizenship have not yet attended any of the ceremonies that would give them that status. It is a very serious matter to write laws or perhaps interpret laws which affect those 1.3 million people but which do not affect the other 13.7 million people who are Australian citizens. This is a problem that has to be faced by Australia as it has to be faced by countries such as the United States of America to which large numbers of migrants are going.

As I said, both men are members of quite large Australian families. Mr Pochi has a wife and three children. The children were born in Australia. Mrs Pochi is an Australian citizen and their three children, who attend Catholic schools in Canberra, are all highly spoken of by their teachers and by the community, both Italian and Australian, in Canberra. Mr Barbaro has five children, all of whom were born in Australia, and a wife who is an Australian citizen. The evidence presented to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal warranted that the offences committed by these men be treated as run-of-the-mill offences committed by Australian citizens.

The other matter to which the Minister referred and perhaps may have elaborated upon in his statement was his heavy reliance upon the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking known as the Woodward Commission. It is true that the findings of the Woodward Commission were not available to Justice Brennan in the case of Pochi. But a detective, Jenkins, who was attached to the Woodward Commission for 15 months, gave evidence in camera to Justice Brennan and Justice Brennan said he would not be persuaded by the evidence given to him by Jenkins to lead him to other than the decision he made to revoke the deportation order. So whilst it is technically true to say that the findings of the Woodward Commission were not available to Brennan, certainly a lot of evidence that was given to the Commission was available to him.

In the case of Barbaro, all the evidence and findings of the Commission were available to Mr Justice Fisher and again he, like Justice Brennan, did not find it sufficient other than to revoke the deportation order. Therefore those matters have been attended to by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Both Brennan and Fisher placed great importance on the question of national interest. This question was part and parcel of the ministerial statement that was made in 1980. It is a matter with which to a very large extent the Opposition concurs. Both Brennan and Fisher could not find that it was in the Australian interest to deport these two people, to break up their families and their homes. Almost all of Barbaro's family have now left Italy. Most of his brothers and sisters and his parents have come to Australia. In fact, he has no relations at all back in Italy. The family of Pochi looks upon itself as an Australian family. Pochi has an added problem that is not referred to in the ministerial statement. This problem ought to be referred to because it is a departmental responsibility. Pochi on two occasions applied for citizenship. On one occassion approval was given for citizenship but notice was not given to Mr Pochi that that approval had been granted. In fact, if it had not been for minor bungling in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs back in 1975 Mr Pochi would have been an Australian citizen. He would have served his sentence after being convicted for supplying Indian hemp and he would now be back among the Australian community without any great concern apart from re-establishing himself in that community.

As I say, there are many problems associated with what we are doing in the Parliament this afternoon. I must say that I dislike intensely the reference in the Minister's statement to matters contained in the Woodward report on drugs. I do not think that anybody who has gone through the reports of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal could refer in any way to these two people as being significant figures in what is described as the 'organisation' in the Minister's statement. I do not think it is possible to find in our hearts that Mr Pochi is guilty because he married a woman whose name is Maria Sergi. A person cannot be found guilty by association with a family which might be named later-years later; almost 20 years later-in association with a crime which all of us find repulsive and repugnant. Mr Pochi cannot be guilty by association because he married a woman called Maria Sergi.

I am not sure that we are not taking this action because we cannot get at the real culprits. I am not sure that we are not taking this action in the Parliament this afternoon because we all-every member of every parliament; every decent person in Australia-are terribly upset at what happened to Donald Mackay. But will this action lessen our guilt and ease our conscience? Will deporting two people who already have served their sentences for the crimes they have committed in Australia do that? It does not seem to me to overcome the problem at all.

I do not think that the Minister is correct in drawing attention to the most drastic parts of the Woodward Royal Commission report in order to fulfil and substantiate the decision he has taken to deport these two men. It may be-I do not know-that the Minister has other information which has not been put before the Parliament. In accordance with the convention of the Parliament, a copy of the Minister's statement was made available to us a short time before we came into the House. We have been going through the material that has been available to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. We have been going through what people in the community and the newspapers have had to say about this matter.

It is not our intention, nor should it be interpreted that it is our intention, to make a political football out of this most serious issue. What we want to do is to have future generations of Australians say that this was the first occasion on which the Parliament of Australia discussed this matter; that a very proper and rational decision was made; that it could be substantiated that it was a proper and rational decision; and that the decision could be looked upon as a precedent. In this case, I do not believe that the Minister's statement outlines a good example of action which we should follow. I would be much happier if we had a lot more material before us, if more time were given to the Parliament to discuss this matter. Perhaps we should even have a cooling off period. I know that people who have been involved in this will say that the matter has been going on for four years. Personally, I do not care if it goes on for 40 years, as long as we make the correct decision, as long as people do not say that every time someone who has not taken out Australian citizenship is caught in a way that is connected with Indian hemp in Australia that person will be deported.

In almost every respect, except for the right to vote for members of parliament , once we extend the great privilege of permanent residence to people, enabling them to live in Australia, they are treated almost as equals with Australian citizens. That is so except in this case. I do not think anyone would interpret the offence of these two people as being a major offence, judging from the sentence both men received. Yet the consequences of such people being caught committing such an offence hangs over their heads and affects their existence, their survival, their livelihood in Australia. On top of that, we can break up their families and deport them. It seems to me that the Parliament should give these matters a little more thought before we proceed further. A lot more material could be discussed in this Parliament. Consequently, I move:
That all words after ''That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
''this House is of the opinion that the deportation orders against Mr Pochi and Mr Barbaro should be suspended pending:

(1) in the case of Mr Pochi, the production by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs of further and more substantial reasons explaining how the findings of the Woodward Royal Commission differed, if at all, from the evidence supplied both in open court and in camera to Mr Justice Brennan at the Administrative Appeals Tribunal hearing;

(2) in the case of Mr Barbaro, the production by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs of further and more substantial reasons explaining how the information available to him about the nature and extent of Mr Barbaro's involvement in commercial marihuana growing differed from material available to Mr Justice Fisher at the Administrative Appeals Tribunal hearing, and
(3) in both cases, the findings of the pending Coronial Inquiry in New South Wales into the death of Donald Mackay.''
I sincerely hope the Parliament sees the wisdom of that amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fry Mr K.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment. In so doing, I appeal to the House to consider this matter very seriously because it is not just a question of deporting two people; it is a question of destroying the unity of two Australian families. I think it is something we should deliberate on very carefully indeed. I think it is a very sad day for not only the Pochi family but also the other family. I am not familiar with the case of the other family, but I am very familiar with the Pochi case. I think what has happened to the members of the Pochi family is a tragedy. I think it is also a very sad day for the cause of natural justice in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Pochi has been before the courts. He was convicted of a minor offence. He won appeals in three courts. He went to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and won his case. He won his case in the Federal Court and, when the Commonwealth sought leave to appeal to the High Court, the Federal Court found in his favour in refusing leave to the Commonwealth to appeal. This person has been subjected to that trauma over several years. The whole family has been held in limbo. This has placed tremendous stresses on the husband and wife as well as the children as they have been going through their school years. Having survived all that, they would have felt resonably sure that the matter was finished, that Mr Pochi had paid his debt to society and would be free to stay in Australia. Of course, what is happening today would be quite impossible in America because the Bill of Rights there prevents double jeopardy or double punishment, which is precisely what is happening in this case.

I am also very concerned about the delay in this case. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) will recall that he allowed me to bring the Pochis to Parliament House to see him before we rose last November. After hearing their story and my representations on their behalf, he did undertake to give a decision within two weeks. That was some three months ago. I would hate to think that these people had been held in limbo for a further three months to serve the purpose of cheap political advantage by bringing this matter on just before the Lowe by-election to show what tough people there are in this Government in relation to drug offences.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cut it out.

—Why did the Minister not announce his decision earlier? Today we have had the Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) saying: 'Let us print this document before we debate it'. He is pre-empting any effect that the debate may have. The Government wants to print it first and get it out into the electorate. It is all right to complain but that is what it looks like.

SPEECH.PARA: As my colleague the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) has said, the whole problem here is that the Minister has accepted hearsay evidence which the Administrative Appeals Tribunal would not accept as a reason for deporting Mr Pochi. I think it is very unfair to the Pochis and to the other defendant that all this information has been given to the House today as though it were fact. It is not fact. It is hearsay evidence produced before a royal commission. The only thing that has been accepted as fact is the finding of the court which resulted in Mr Pochi being given a two-year gaol term. He was found on a farm cultivating marihuana. He did not have it in his hand. He was not selling it. He was not smoking it. He happened to be on the farm. That is a fact. This is hearsay evidence and it should not be presented to this House as fact. I am astounded that the Minister can accept hearsay evidence and present it to this Parliament as fact when a learned judge has said it is hearsay evidence which he cannot accept as a basis for deporting Mr Pochi. That is the gist of the whole case. The sad part about this case is that, having been through all these legal procedures, the Minister just overrides the decisions with a stroke of the pen. I am terribly disappointed. I know the Minister has had a difficult decision to make and he has taken a long time to make it. I also have reason to believe that , whilst he may have had some sympathy, other people in the Cabinet did not and that he was under tremendous pressure to deport these people.

The other thing in the Minister's statement which I think is very misleading is the inference that these people had a lot of money and that they lived in some sort of luxury far beyond their means. The fact is that Pochi borrowed money to build a retail outlet for wine. One can speculate on what he was going to use it for but there is nothing mysterious about that. He borrowed money to erect a building from which he was going to retail wine. He had to withdraw from that when all this blew up. The Pochi family lived in a very modest house. It was not a luxurious house. It was very poorly furnished. I have been into their house. They have since had to sell the house to meet their legal expenses.

These people have been under this pressure for five years. They have been under constant pressure and constant threat. They have been in and out of the courts. They have spent over $30,000 on legal fees. If he was Mr Big, which they tried to claim he was, someone would have been backing him for his legal fees, but no one has. Pochi has had to sell his house. The whole family has had to go out and accept work at every opportunity. They have done cleaning work and painting work . The kids have bucked in and done odd jobs to try to get enough money for them to meet their obligations and to preserve their dignity in the community. They had a lot of dignity in this community. When this matter first blew up a petition was circulated and within a couple of days there were over a thousand names signed on the petition supporting the good character of the Pochi family. There is no question about that.

I think this House really has to think about how this decision is going to affect the family. I ask honourable members to think of a family they know with a wife, husband and three children one of whom is at university and the other two are at school. What is going to happen to the family? It is like sending a man to Siberia. This man has not been in Italy for years. He has no relatives there. His wife has no relatives there. Yet he is going to be sent off. What is going to happen to these people? It is going to be a tremendous wrench on them all and on all of their friends and relatives. This Government is just breaking up the family. What is it going to achieve? I think the big weakness in the Minister's argument as set out in the statement is that he has not really considered the fundamental question which could have justified his deporting Mr Pochi, and that is whether Pochi is likely to offend again. I suggested to the Minister that that was fundamental to the whole case. There is not the slightest shred of evidence that he would offend again. Nothing that he has done in the meantime would indicate that he would offend again.

Members of the Pochi family have lived a very poor life, a fairly mean life, in order to meet their obligations. They have embraced every opportunity to work and they have been able to meet their obligations as they have fallen due. He has not put a foot wrong legally or in any other way. I do not see that there is any justification at all for believing that he would offend again. If he was involved, he has learned his lesson and he has learned it in a very hard and cruel way by being harassed, in and out of the courts, over five years, spending over $30,000 in legal fees as well as putting up with the strain that this has placed on his marriage and his family and on the relationships with other families and the children's school mates. Fortunately the community has been very supportive of these people. He has been punished enough and to deport him now is a vindictive act. It will achieve nothing except destroy the family and break up the unity of the family. I do not know what is going to happen to the family. It is a very serious position. I think we ought to think very carefully about this decision. I think it is a blatant denial of natural justice to this man, who was convicted on a fairly minor offence and who has served his time, to put this draconian measure on him for his deportation to a strange country, which is what this means to Mr Pochi. He is an Australian in every sense, except that, because of administrative bungling he was not made a citizen.

I suggest that the idea that he could be a Mr Big is a product of the imagination of the police. They desperately needed a Mr Big. They could not get the right man but we all know of other people who are Australian citizens and very involved in the drug trade. Some of them are supposed to be very respectable citizens. Some have even been knighted. They get off scot free. Yet they pick on this poor Mr Pochi, who, according to the court, was on the very fringe of it and try to build him up as a Mr Big. If I brought him in here now I could not convince anyone that he was a Mr Big. He is a very small man indeed. He has not been terribly successful. He is a battler and no one could look less like a Mr Big than could Mr Pochi. To suggest otherwise is a product of the imagination of the police.

When I first took up this question Mr MacKellar was the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. He pointed to a secret file and said: 'Mr Fry, if you knew what was in there you would not be supporting these people'. He did not know that I did know what was 'in there', because I had received a copy of the police report. Again, it was 100 per cent hearsay evidence. There was nothing substantial in it at all. It was not just my opinion that this was hearsay evidence; it was Mr Justice Brennan's view also. I cannot accept it as a basis for deporting Mr Pochi.

In the interests of natural justice, he should be given a fair go. He has not been given it, nor has his wife, nor will his children if he is deported. I plead with the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) and the House to accept this amendment, which really does not resolve the issue at all but merely says: 'Let us have another look at the evidence. Do not let us make a hasty decision that will ruin two families and achieve nothing. Let us have another look at it. Let us defer it pending the acquisition of better information by the Parliament and the people concerned'.

I understand that further legal action may be taken. It is very unfair to these people that this information has been given out today. I refer particularly to that which came from the Minister, in quoting hearsay evidence while not making it clear that it was hearsay, and putting it before the Parliament as fact. I want honourable members to be quite clear that it is merely hearsay evidence. It has not been accepted as fact, not proven in a court, and was positively rejected by Mr Justice Brennan of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It is the grossest miscarriage of justice to deport the husband and father of citizens of Australia, when there is no evidence that he will offend again, thus destroying his family. I ask honourable members to consider this amendment very seriously indeed. It merely delays action; it does not dismiss the matter. Let us be sure that we are doing the right thing and that we are not committing a gross miscarriage of natural justice in regard to people who are Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe that any sensible Australian would question the need for power to deport. I do not believe that has been questioned by the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young). Although I did not agree with everything that he said, I rather tend to agree with the spirit in which he approached what is unquestionably an important matter.

SPEECH.PARA: When a decision is made to deport, the Minister who has the ultimate responsibility must go through two processes. Firstly, he must make up his mind upon the facts. That is not an easy matter, in complex cases in particular. Then he must exercise a discretion. Having formed his view upon the facts, he determines whether it is in the interests of the country that the person whose case is before him should remain or should go.

As I believe the honourable member for Port Adelaide has acknowledged, these are difficult decisions. We all know that in making difficult decisions it is possible to come down on one side or the other. That having been said, I believe it worth while that the House examine one or two matters which relate to the case of Mr Pochi. I can understand that the honourable member for Port Adelaide would not have had time to examine the matter exhaustively. I am in the same position, but some points should be examined, and drawn out.

First, for the purpose of getting the legal record straight, I remind the House that Mr Pochi appealed to Mr Justice Brennan, as he then was-he is now in the High Court-and His Honour made a decision that was favourable to him. It was made upon the facts. Mr Justice Brennan's approach to the question of fact- finding, according to my very hasty reading of his decision, was somewhat different from the way in which the Royal Commissioner approached the same question-which again illustrates the kind of difficulty that these matters throw up. There was an appeal by the Minister from His Honour's decision, on a point of law only, to the Federal Court. It was disallowed. The Federal Court did not go into the facts. Then an application was made for special leave to appeal to the High Court. That Court, after examining the matter, decided that it was not a case in which special leave should be granted. That again did not involve an investigation by the High Court of the facts. So we should have those points squarely in mind.

We should also have in mind, quite contrary to what the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Fry) has said, that there is no question of double jeopardy involved. Nor would the position be different in the United States. The two issues, conviction for criminal offences and deportation, are quite different. As to hearsay, we should put that argument to one side, or at least clarify it. Hearsay evidence is taken into account for the very good reason that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act provides in section 33 (1):
In a proceeding before the Tribunal-
(c) The Tribunal is not bound by the rules of evidence but may inform itself on any matter in such manner as it thinks appropriate.

That includes looking at hearsay evidence and giving such weight to hearsay evidence as is thought appropriate. Those of us who have spent a long time kicking around courts of different kinds learn after a while that hearsay evidence, while often excluded, frequently-not always-has fairly high probative value.

Lastly, I am bound to say, in answer to one thing that the honourable member for Fraser said, that it is quite contemptible to seek to divert this argument by referring to the kinds of things that he was talking about-that some individual who is a knight has been involved in the same sort of business. It may be that his own involvement in the case of Mr Pochi-I understand from one of the decisions that his office prepared a petition which was presented to this House-has somewhat overtaken his judgment in that area.

Let us examine one or two of the things that were said by the Royal Commissioner about Mr Pochi. I confine myself to Mr Pochi for the very good reason that I have not had the chance to read what the Royal Commissioner said about the other gentleman or indeed to go fully through to the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not going to take Woodward seriously, are you?

—The Royal Commissioner was appointed in the State of New South Wales and was a man of great experience in fact-finding. I want to refer to pages 677 and 678 of the report. The Royal Commissioner said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am satisfied that Pochi was actively engaged in assisting in the production and distribution of marihuana. This was also consistent with the verdict of the jury. He was probably a more senior member of the organisation than either of Scarfo, Gambacorta or the two Agrestas. This could be the reason for him being taken into partnership in Vignali Wines with Sergi and Trimboli.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falconer Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment on some of the aspects of the debate that have risen this afternoon in this House. I do not want to comment specifically on the merits of he cases before us, especially the case of Mr Pochi, which has been quoted at some length by a number of honourable members who have participated in the debate. Firstly I want to compliment the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young), who led for the Opposition, on the way in which he responded to the statement of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee). He put a different point of view, but it was a view that ought to be expressed in a debate of this nature.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has exercised a discretion available to him under the Act which he was required to exercise and I think it is the sort of discretion which ought to be the subject of review by this chamber. So I think the honourable member for Port Adelaide approached this matter in a very responsible and moderate way and that this ought to be acknowledged by the House. I am disappointed that the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Charles Young) has not participated in the debate because he made it clear by way of interjection that he disagreed with the approach being taken by the Opposition. I had the clear impression from the comments he made by way of interjection that he agreed with the decision that the Minister had reached. So if there is time for him to participate I would like to hear what he has to say on the subject because that would ensure that this matter is fully reviewed by this House.

I want to speak in more detail about one or two comments made by other honourable members. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) said that the Minister shouls stay his hand and allow the subject to be looked at in further detail. The fact is that I am aware that the Minister has been exercising his mind on this subject for many months. Indeed, we ought to acknowledge, as I have already said, that the legislation is framed in a way that allows the Minister a discretion to reject a recommendation of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal if he feels there are sufficient grounds for him to do so. I think we ought to dwell on that point because if the Minister has a discretion which is vested on him by both Houses of this Parliament we ought not automatically say that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has made a recommendation in a certain direction that Minister ought to accept that recommendation without question. He has, by virtue of legislation of this Parliament, a responsibility imposed upon him to review the decision or the recommendation of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and to see whether there are other grounds, other factors, which he should take into consideration in reaching a decision about whether to deport.

His involvement in the marihuana industry was promoted by more than a mere love for horticulture. He was, like the others, involved in it for what he could make out of it. One could reasonably assume that he had already made some money from it. In those circumstances he was, like his associates in the industry, in possession from time to time of money for which he could give no truthful and acceptable explanation. It therefore had to be laundered. Two of the practised methods of doing this was by organised 'betting wins' and 'loans' from relatives and friends. This is just what Pochi did. $65,900 he attributed to such loans and $24,448 to betting wins, much of the latter becoming available at a time when needed.
To interpolate, one could only wish for such friends and for such luck. Page 677 continues:

If one considers the situation in reverse based upon his allegations, the result is interesting. All money accretions, upon his story, came legitimately. So he received nothing from the marihuana industry. He was not involved in it. He was wrongly convicted by the jury. He was unaware of the true position at Coleambally.
That is where the property in question was situated. The report continues:
