He, a resident of Canberra, had come to Griffith for a social visit in the course of which for the purposes of enjoying a picnic or barbeque (without benefit of wives or children) he and a number of other males travelled approximately thirty miles into unattractive country on a made road and then some further ten to fifteen miles on unmade roads through paddocks and eleven locked gates to the farm where much of the 'picnic' involved 'chipping parsnips' in the heat of the day at a time when flies were plentiful. At the place of the picnic it was obvious that there was provision available for reasonably comfortable living in a caravan supplied with electricity and air conditioning.
I go now to the conclusions the Commissioner expressed concerning Mr Pochi, who was represented by Mr Murphy of Queen's Counsel. The Commissioner stated:
My conclusions concerning Luigi Pochi, expressed in short form, are:
1. He was undoubtedly involved in the growing of the crop on the Coleambally farm in November, 1975, and could be expected to share in the proceeds.

2. No direct evidence is available to involve Pochi in the production of the earlier year. There is evidence, however, of him receiving financial benefits which could not be attributed to the pursuit of any legitimate occupation.

3. That he is a brother-in-law of Antonio Sergi, that Antonio Sergi and Trimboli were involved in one or more earlier marihuana cultivations, and that Pochi was 'invited' to become a substantial shareholder in Vignali Wines in Canberra. Because of his involvement, it is not surprising that such an invitation would have been issued to him. Pochi did not receive any money either from gambling or from loans made to him by friends or relatives.
4. The monies therefore that came to him from these sources in the early part of 1975 were contributions emanating from an earlier crop or in anticipation of his share in the 1975/76 crop.

In the very short time available, and taking account of the honourable member for Port Adelaide's point that it is very difficult to conduct any kind of trial in this Parliament, it is worthwhile referring to one point that arises from the decision of Mr Justice Brennan. Mr Justice Brennan, who came to the conclusion that in all the circumstances Mr Pochi should not be deported, did not accept what he had to say about the source of funds since Mr Pochi, the fortunate recipient of loans and gambling wins, had got together very quickly a large amount of money for the purpose of purchasing a business. For those who want to look at it at a later stage I refer to page 263 of volume 26 of the Australian Law Reports. After detailing the way in which Mr Pochi allegedly got together $ 100,000 for the purpose of purchasing an interest in a business, Mr Justice Brennan said:

It may thus be seen that the contribution to the purchase of the Vignali Wines premises was funded by loans of the order of $61,000 made by close relatives or friends, cash of $5000, betting wins of the order of $11,500, a bank loan of $15 ,000, savings or business income of the order of $6000, and proceeds of sale of the shop and stock of $19,000.

I do not believe much of the applicant's account of assembling this finance, partly because I do not believe some of the accounts as to the particular items, and partly because I do not believe that a commitment to the payment of $117,000 or thereabouts would have been made prior to 4 June 1975 without knowing that the money was available.

That is, a commitment was made and the money then came into Mr Pochi's hands. After examining Mr Pochi's history of betting, this goes to one of the points which is obviously central to the mind of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee)-the Judge summarised, on page 267, as follows:
The history of the applicant's betting with Crawford--
Crawford was a bookmaker-

was remarkable. His credit betting opened on 18 January 1975 when he lost $1400. Thereafter, his winning days produced funds which were used to assist in the payment of the deposit, the payment of the stamp duty and the balance of the purchase price. He then had a losing day in August and, at the time when the first period of the bank bridging advance was expiring, he had another winning run. His betting with Crawford ceased in April of 1976. Although he was not a regular race-goer, he won $28,500 on 26 bets, and lost only 32 bets which cost him $4910.

I hope I can be excused for making this comment: If one believes that story-the judge obviously did not-one will believe anything at all. The question therefore must be asked: Where did the money come from? I put it that that question supports very strongly the conclusion which has been reached by the Minister. I conclude by saying this: I think all of us look to the right result being reached in deportation cases. Every honourable member of this House is concerned with the interests of this country and when it comes to whether or not people should stay or go I do not think party affiliations have any influence on our views. Certainly they should not and I do not think it applies to members of either side of the House. I said at the beginning that minds can differ on a case such as this but, looking at Mr Pochi's case, must we not ask ourselves, if he did not tell the truth about this matter; where did the money come from, what was the likely source? And, is it not a case where bipartisanship in terms of approach to these matters should prevail? If we are to seek to try every single case where differences may arise irrespective of who is in office, it will not do very much for the furtherance of the interests of this country as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The matter before the House is a grave issue because, although deportation is not in itself a criminal punishment, the consequences of deportation may often be far more destructive to the lives of the deportee and his family than any sentence of imprisonment. Therefore, when we consider the facts of this case and the arguments presented by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee), there are a number of important principles about which I think all honourable members can be agreed. There can be no doubt-there is no doubt-of the Minister's right of discretion. But I believe, and I believe the Minister would agree, that that right and its exercise must be tempered and applied within the established principles of law and in accordance with the principles of natural justice. The Minister himself has recognised that fact. I turn to the seventh page of his statement, where he states:

SPEECH.PARA: Deportation is never ordered as a punishment and should not be accepted as a second punishment. Its purpose is to remove from the community persons who have demonstrated by their conduct that they are unacceptable to the overwhelming majority of Australians.

That is the criterion that the Minister has put forward to this House. I believe it is a proper and appropriate criterion, and I believe it is upon the basis of the Minister's own criterion that we should ask ourselves whether the Minister's discretion has been properly applied in this case.

Let me say right from the outset that I do not believe there is any sympathy at all in Australian society, nor in this Parliament, for the professional drug trafficker who is prepared, for the sake of personal gain, to destroy the lives of young Australians. This Parliament and its members should say to the people of Australia and to the international drug trade that the full force of the law will be applied to protect the lives of young Australian citizens. I believe that we are all agreed on that. But in asserting these positions we must not abandon other principles which are of equal importance to our society. In our adherence to the rule of law we must remember that we are a society made up of immigrants. The development of our society has depended upon immigration. Therefore, when the Minister exercises his discretion, he must do so in a way which is in accord with well established legal principles and concepts so that there can be no doubt in the minds not only of the immigrant community but also of the whole broader Australian community that this discretion is not the exercise of some whim or of some preferred political preference, but is in fact applied objectively, sincerely and on the basis of all the relevant evidence.

Having applied that test, let me say this: I was unfamiliar with the details of this case until I became involved earlier this morning. Our former colleagues and present colleagues representing this area-I refer to the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Fry), the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) and a former member for Canberra-are on record as having supported the arguments put forward by a large number of residents in Canberra that Mr Pochi ought to be allowed to stay in Australia. That is something that I think undoubtedly the Minister would have borne in mind.

I am concerned in terms of the application of principles and the way in which the Minister has today put his case to the House. He has recognised the importance of the findings of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and he has also recognised, as Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, that it is a serious matter of principle when the Minister exercises a discretion which flies in the face of a decision of that Tribunal. I believe that when the Minister acts in that way he must be prepared to come into the House and justify the basis upon which that decision was reached.

To date the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) has endeavoured to justify that exercise of discretion, as indeed has the Minister, by reference to the findings of the Woodward Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking. I put this to the honourable member for North Sydney and to the Minister: Commissioners, in their findings in royal commissions, will adduce facts produced on the basis of evidence that comes before them. But the mere finding that a man has not told the truth, the mere finding that a man may have been involved in the drug trade and the mere fact that he may have been convicted for that do not of themselves entitle one to argue, on the basis of those findings alone, that that person-in this case, Mr Pochi-is someone whose continued presence in Australia represents a threat to Australian society.

It may well be that if we were to ask Mr Justice Woodward, but we cannot, he might well say: 'Pochi has been sentenced, he has been tried, and he has discharged his debt to Australian society. On all the evidence that I have before me I do not think he constitutes a permanent threat to Australian society '. That is the standard and criterion. I remind the honourable member for North Sydney, as I would remind the Minister, that that very issue was fully examined. It was the subject of a full judicial assessment by Mr Justice Brennan. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal was asked to determine the central issue. It was not asked to examine the applicant's role in drug trafficking. It was not asked to examine whether it was a good or a bad thing that he may or may not have laundered money. It was asked to make the critical decision, on all the evidence available, whether it would be a better or a worse thing for Australian society that this man be deported, that his existing Australian family be broken up or faced with that most terrible of conflicts of whether his wife, who is an Australian citizen and his children, who are all Australian citizens, all vouched for by their own ethnic community and by the broader Australian community, should have to follow this man into exile. That is the issue. What we as a House are therefore entitled to expect from the Minister are not references to general unspecified allegations in the Woodward report. What the House is entitled to from the Minister is the very specific allegation that, having examined the judgment of Mr Justice Brennan, for very specific reasons the Minister is unable to join Mr Justice Brennan in his conclusions and the Minister is therefore satisfied that that man's continued presence in Australian society constitutes a threat to our community.

I have spent some hours examining very carefully the legal processes that were followed by Mr Justice Brennan, his view of the evidence and the way in which the evidence was adduced. Again, I remind the House that his was a very specific responsibility. There can be no doubt in my mind that any member of this House who is prepared to trouble himself to read this judgment in full will be impressed not only with the application of legal principle but also with the high and appropriate standards which His Honour applied in that case with determining this very important issue.

The great issues of civil liberty are never determined on the basis of exemplary characters, the perfect citizens. They always arise in this sort of case. It is the application of those principles and our capacity as a community to maintain those principles in respect of someone about whom many of the allegations made by the honourable member for North Sydney can be sustained, that test the very fabric of our society and the very principles to which we adhere. What did Mr Justice Brennan say? I cannot do any better and I do not believe I can more eloquently examine the evidence. As my colleague the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) has pointed out, in considering this evidence Mr Justice Brennan did not regard himself, as indeed he is not legally bound to, as bound by the formal laws of evidence. He was concerned to pursue the truth in order to answer the very real question: Does this man's presence in Australian society constitute a threat? In order to pursue that question he had before him a senior member of the New South Wales Police Force who was deeply involved in every aspect of the drug investigation. That evidence was given in camera, with Mr Pochi's lawyers present. That is how concerned His Honour was to see that all the evidence was before him. He realised the gravity of the decision he had to make.

It is all very well to refer to a finding made by Mr Justice Woodward in respect of another matter. Mr Justice Brennan said when referring to the funds, upon which the honourable member for North Sydney rested so much of his case--
There is no evidence to connect the applicant with marihuana prior to his arrest in November 1975. It is unknown whether the clandestine funds, whatever their source, belonged to the applicant.
Mr Justice Brennan goes on to say:
The evidence given to me in camera--
He was clearly searching for the evidence-
did not live up to the expectations in that it lacked the cogency which would support a finding of fact against the applicant.
He continues:

There are ample grounds for suspecting that the applicant was so involved, but the evidence does not prove it. When an alien who is an established resident becomes liable to deportation under s 12, the general rule must be that the conduct which is relied on to show that a deportation order is in the best interests of Australia must be proved, not merely suspected.

I repeat those words: 'must be proved, not merely suspected'. Mr Justice Brennan goes on to say that on the basis of all the evidence before him, onus of proof had not been discharged and therefore he found that the order in respect of Mr Pochi should not be granted. He concluded by saying:
It is certain that deportation of the applicant would destroy or gravely damage a growing Australian family and it would be a grave detriment not only to them but to Australia.

The burden that rests upon the Minister, for whom I have great respect, is to be able to conclude and to the satisfaction of honourable members to say: 'I have additional evidence which indicates that, for all of his integrity, for all of his application of judicial principle, that was a finding in which Mr Justice Brennan was in error'. If the Minister can discharge that obligation-and I think that is the obligation-I for one would be prepared to say that the Minister has not merely acted responsibly in this matter but has applied the principles of natural justice and that I am satisfied that all the principles have been applied. Having looked at the judgment and having heard the Minister's statement , I do not believe that, on the basis of the decision that has been made, and on the basis of the importance of maintaining judicial principles, the rule of law and the principle of natural justice, any member of this House can be satisfied that the Minister has moved the burden that rests upon him and that this man ought to be torn from his family and his family ought to be confronted with the choice of following him into exile.

I point out that this man would not be in that position-to adopt the simple phraseology of the High Court-if his earlier application for naturalisation had not been bungled by the Minister's Department. This is not a situation in which we should apply anything other than the basic rules of justice. I doubt whether they have been properly applied in this case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourchier Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to debate this very emotive matter which has been brought forward by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee), there are one or two areas on which I should like to touch and which have, I believe, not yet been raised. But before doing so I should like to make one or two comments in relation to remarks of previous speakers. The Minister, in taking the action that he has, has made it quite clear to the House that it was not a hasty action. It is an action which I think even the Opposition has acknowledged has been taken only after many months, possibly years, of investigation. As Opposition members have acknowledged, he is a very competent and responsible Minister. He certainly would not have taken such action without the very best of recommendations and the assurative that the action he was taking was correct.

SPEECH.PARA: Having acknowledged that point it would be fair also to mention-I do not say this lightly or in any complimentary manner, but simply mention it-that the Minister is well known throughout the ethnic community of Australia as a very compassionate Minister. I do not think that would be denied by any honourable member. His approaches to all matters in relation to immigration have been made in a very forthright and open manner. I know that he has taken every action to weigh up all the problems relating to this matter. There would be no doubt in my mind and, I am sure, in the minds of other members on this side of the House and , I hope, honourable members on the other side, that the Minister would have taken into consideration the heartbreak and tragedy that is occurring in the families connected to this issue.

Nevertheless, the facts are that we have a situation, outlined in the Minister' s statement, which calls for deportation. Deportation is not a very nice thing. In fact, it would have to be the ultimate action to be taken in a specific case. In taking that action, the Minister is also aware that he is taking an action to protect in a large way the good name of the Italian community and other ethnic communities in this country who unfortunately, perhaps because of media response -I do not know-or whatever, whenever there are any allegations against a member of their particular ethnic group, are generally labelled, all or many of them, as being associated or mixed in with such activities. By taking this action the Minister is making it quite clear that the very responsible and respected ethnic groups in this country will know the full facts, that they will have the opportunity of supporting-indeed I believe they will do so-the Minister's action because, after all, it will help to clear their good names and their reputations in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a lot of rot.

—It is not rot; it is a fact. The other fact is that there has been a growing, widespread concern in this country, ever since the terrible tragedy concerning Mr Mackay which was mentioned by the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young), which has led to a great call for greater penalties in regard to all sorts of drug abuse and drug trading. The honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) also mentioned that.

SPEECH.PARA: The people in the country areas have noticed that there has been a growth in the growing of marihuana in remote farm areas. This growth has been caused by people being brought into the country, financed to come here, and financed to go on to farms when they probably did not have the financial backing to do so. Once on the farm the proviso was that they would provide a crop of marihuana. Police records exist in Victoria, New South Wales and probably South Australia to support what I am saying: That there has been a lot of discovery over the last few years by the police in their efforts to wipe out this practice. But what is happening is that the relatively innocent, in the sense of being newcomers to the field and being put on a farm and being caught, suffer the penalty of a small fine or alternatively, if gaoled, they find the farm is kept going for them in their absence or that the fine has been paid by the organisation, so called. There is no doubt that this organisation, that most people know better by the name of the Mafia, does exist. The Minister is making it quite clear in his actions that this country will not tolerate that. It is a tragedy for the people concerned who are the innocents associated with the particular people.

But surely we must not overlook one simple fact: The people to whom we are referring today were invited or allowed to enter this country to become good citizens at a future time. They were given all the opportunities to taking whatever benefits they could of this country in every proper and legitimate manner. Instead they chose to take illegal attitudes to try to make money in the quick and easy way, to breed by the crime of providing drugs to the families of Australian citizens. That point must not be overlooked. They must accept the responsibilities that go with the actions they have taken.

It is all very well to stand here and be concerned about a certain section, but let us be a little concerned about all those others, the families throughout the country that are heartbroken and have had tragedy thrust upon them because of the action of certain people in providing drugs. I congratulate the honourable member for Melbourne Ports and the honourable member for Port Adelaide for their very rational approach to this matter. I am sure that the Minister will do as they have asked; that is, give the matter the most serious consideration and make sure that the proper decision is reached. I am sure those honourable members would agree and hope that in reaching that decision consideration will be given not only to the people who have been involved in the criminal activities-unfortunately their families, innocent as they may be, may be associated with it-but also to the many tragedies that might be prevented in the future by taking this action.

The honourable member for Port Adelaide mentioned that very point when he said that future generations of Australians may well look back on this first action in this Parliament in relation to deportation. I agree with him. But they may well say that that action has stopped a course of progress which may have been to their detriment or to the detriment of this country in the future had that step not been taken. I know that the Minister has given this matter his absolute and most serious consideration. He has looked at it in every possible way. He received the best information and proof he could before he took such a drastic step. The honourable member for Port Adelaide and, I believe, the honourable member for Melbourne Ports have indicated that, whilst the Opposition calls on the Government and the Minister to be very careful to make sure that the right decision is reached, when this decision is reached the Opposition will also support it in the very best interests of the future of this country. I hope that is so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment put forward by the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young). I would like to draw attention to the sophistry of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). He talked blithely today and said that there is no double jeopardy. Of course we know that in legalistic terms crime and deportation are different subjects. But I put it to this House that they are clearly very closely related to both people and their families. For these people the double jeopardy very clearly exists and they are obviously paying twice. Not only the guilty parties but also their entire families are paying twice. The honourable member for North Sydney discredited the accumulation of wealth, as did Mr Justice Brennan. I have a lot of dealings with ethnic families and the amount of money--
—I would never denigrate Mr Justice Brennan under any circumstances, nor would I seek to do so.
—If the honourable member would like to make a speech later I am sure he will be allowed to have another go even if we are not.
—Don't misrepresent what I say. I am here listening to you.

—I intend to stick very closely to the facts, a thing which I think my friend should do in future. The point is that these families can raise this sort of money from friends and relatives. We are talking about only a very small amount of money-a mere $46,000. At the moment I am mediating in a similar sort of deal in the goldfields in which money was lent within families and now there is a hassle over it. The sum of money involved far exceeds this rather small amount. The honourable member for North Sydney blithely said: 'Can you believe the story about racing'? He entirely discredited it. I admit that it is an unlikely story. But did the honourable member for North Sydney ever question the Premier of Western Australia, Mr Ray O'Connor, who had seven consecutive wins on a double-up basis at the Belmont course and took out of the ring half a million dollars? Did he ever question that? Is he prepared to say in this House that that is a likely story? Of course he is not. That is the sort of sophistry I have come to expect from the honourable member for North Sydney. However, I will say that if I am ever guilty of a crime I will certainly seek him as a lawyer.

SPEECH.PARA: We must now look at the national interest. It must be the overwhelming consideration. Is the national interest of this country served in any way by denying natural justice? How can it be? The cause of natural justice is one of the things that, in our society, we hold most dear. There is no way that national interest can be served if it appears to or in fact does impinge on natural justice. How about the hardship to the family? Trauma will obviously be inflicted on this family. How can this be in any way in the national interest of Australia? It could well be in the national interest of a section of the community which seeks to divert attention from the real issues and to claim the front page of the newspapers with this sort of thing when these pages should be devoted to the real issues that beset this country.

One of the speakers on the Government side talked about the Mafia. He thinks we can control the Mafia in this country by deporting two obviously small fry. How would that affect the mafia? What is wanted in this country is a full parliamentary inquiry into drugs. This is something that the Australian Labor Party has consistently supported and called for. It would do far more good than this punitive action which is being taken so that the powers that be can appear to be doing something. It is clearly the case that the government is looking for a scapegoat and it has found it. By all accounts these men are two very small Mr Bigs.

We in this House have been subjected to and bombarded by the emotive issue of drugs and the shock horror of drugs. We are talking about marihuana. The fact is that there are many honourable members opposite whom I would not mind naming who would be a damn sight better off if they stuck to marihuana and left alcohol alone. Alcohol is far more damaging to them. The truth is that this is a drug that does have a very large amount of public acceptance, whether honourable members opposite like it or not. It is not seen by the mass of the people in this country in the same terms as heroin, cocaine and all the other very dangerous drugs. But the Government does not hesitate to lump them together in one emotive thing-a drug dealer. I have no doubt that the man was guilty. He was convicted and he paid his price for his guilt. Mr Justice Brennan, in his summing up, recognised all these facts and all this evidence. In his wisdom he decided that deportation was not an appropriate course to follow. I think that it would serve us all very well if a stand was made by this Parliament against the authoritarians who exist in our society, many of whom pervade the corridors of the bureaucracy.

We have heard mention of how the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs ( Mr Macphee) is a good and honourable man. I do not question that. All I say is that by their deeds you shall know them. I think the time will come when this decision will be seen as an exercise in authoritarian, bureaucratic power to hide the bunglings of not only his Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs but also the police investigation. What have we asked the Minister to do? We have simply asked the Minister to withdraw the deportation order pending further inquiries so that he can make known to us the information that he purports to have, the information to which, in a free society, I think we are entitled. Is that too much to ask the Minister?

We have the case in New South Wales of a coronial court inquiring into the disappearance of Donald Mackay. We have heard this case linked very emotionally with that case. There is not a shred of evidence to connect them but people may think so. In fact, I am surprised that honourable members opposite did not actually say that either of these gentlemen murdered Mr Mackay. I think it would be a very proper course to follow to wait until this inquiry is finished. To me the Mackay case has many of the hallmarks of the Azaria Chamberlain case. This is something I am sure the Minister does not want on his conscience if subsequent events prove that to be true. All we are asking is that the Minister stay his hand. After all, the Minister stays his hand for great lengths of time on other occasions. Why, is it too much of a hardship to do so now to avoid the unnecessary hardship that the members of this family will face, or in the view of the Government, are the members of the family guilty by implication? It is true that there was a connection by marriage with the Sergi family. Are we all to be guilty because of our relations and our in-laws? That is the implication of the Government's proposed action. I appeal again to the Minister, in the name of natural justice and the Australian concept of the fair go, to hold his hand until he can produce to this House the additional evidence upon which he makes his judgment and until we can have the benefit of the inquiry currently taking place in New South Wales. I do not feel that this is a lot to ask and I do not believe that the people of Australia will feel that it is a lot to ask.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented .
—Does the honourable member wish to make a personal explanation?

—Yes. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie said that what I had said denigrated or discredited-I am not sure which word he used-Mr Justice Brennan. I interjected to make my position quite clear but I should like it to be made even plainer. I in no way cast any reflections upon Mr Justice Brennan, a judge of whom I have the highest opinion. Nor would I ever do that in this House of any judge of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is proper no doubt that the legal processes behind the conviction of the two men for crimes should be discussed here today because of this deportation decision. However, there is no doubt that they were guilty of the crimes that have been elucidated. None of the discussions here has in any way tried to negate that fact. On that fact, and the further information which the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) includes in his statement to the House, the Minister has made a practical decision concerning the effect that the deportation will have on the national good. It is quite wrong-and in fact the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) does not elevate this debate by doing so-to talk of scapegoats. I remind him that the report of the Woodward Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, to which the Minister refers effectively in his study of the situation, was set up by the Labor Government in New South Wales.
—It was also available to Brennan.

—It was an admirable thing for the New South Wales Government to do. But it would seem that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie does not like the results that the Commission turned up. He does not want to see the results. He does not want to take notice of them and, of course, he cannot look to the origin of that commission to throw any blame on the part of the Government, so he talks of scapegoats. It is quite irresponsible of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie to talk of scapegoats when the Minister quite clearly has taken the overall view, correctly, that these two gentlemen were deeply involved in the drug culture in Australia. This is not an isolated crime. They were members of organised crime. There is a great difference.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the greatest threats to the social fabric of this country comes from organised crime and any member of this community who has anything to do with a large city understands the unprovable but known things that are occurring in those communities in relation to the spread of organised crime. It is an enormous threat to the community. I commend the Minister, not for issuing or being involved in a double penalty, but for removing from Australia these people who could conceivably still be influential in the drug culture of this country in the future. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie referred in his speech to the fact that marihuana is less than something or other; I have forgotten his exact remarks. Prosecutions are now pending in many cities where drug dealers are being charged for the sale and commercial involvement in marihuana and harder drugs. They go together in the drug culture so far as their spread and dissemination throughout this community is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is also not true.

—I refer the honourable gentleman to existing charges which are being laid. One should not comment further on them because they are not settled. But it is a well known factor. The honourable member has not studied the reports of the commissions and the various pieces of evidence that are available to him. In South Australia, we have seen large efforts at drug growing and the production of marihuana. As I have said, people in the community are not so concerned with the single one-off operation. It is the organised factor which is so damaging and so frightening. Within the last several months there was a find to the south of Adelaide of a marihuana plantation which was reputed to have a street value of $60m. To my knowledge, no arrests have yet been made with regard to that find although the plantation was known to exist about three weeks before the police went there and destroyed it. It was an extremely well organised operation with land clearing, irrigation systems and attention given to the plants through their formative growth months. I understand that no arrests have been made because of the intricacies of the lease arrangements which had been set up. The lease had been passed from one person to another and, as I understand it, the final operators are not known by the law. It seems to me a rather tedious excuse but that is what is said and, of course, it illustrates the sophistication of organised crime which has developed in this country. These two gentlemen have been a part of it.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no point in anyone opposite saying that these two people are one-off operators who have operated individually. I repeat: They are part of organised crime. As far as I am concerned, and as far as the general community is concerned, the penalties for the original crimes were not severe enough for that organised factor. People do serve their time or pay their fine. They spend, say, a year in prison or pay a fine which is quite minimal compared with the rewards of being a drug grower or a drug distributor. Something will have to be done in this community to increase the penalties for such offences and to make sure that the deterrent is of a sufficient size or effect to have some influence in the depression of drug growing and drug distribution.

It is a sad fact that their families will be affected. But the administration of the law or of Government policy is not confined simply to these families. Every imposition of a gaol penalty produces a very sad effect on the family of the convicted. Therefore, why should we select the families of these two men for special sympathy compared with the thousands of other families in Australia of people who have been convicted of criminal acts? No satisfaction was given by members opposite as to why these families should be selected for special sympathy. The families I would select for sympathy are those who are affected and sometimes destroyed as a result of the drug trade. They are the ones that have the sympathy of most Australians. But I do not want to develop that highly emotive issue. That is the sympathy I want to express. For that reason I give my wholehearted support to the Minister for his action in protecting Australia in this way. Whilst I have represented many migrants and their families with their problems over the years, and I welcome their entry into Australia, I do not welcome anyone from overseas who comes here, does not take up citizenship but maintains citizenship from elsewhere, enters into criminal acts and believes that he or she can use this country and abuse its hospitality. Surely, we are not so subservient that we can take that view. I commend the Minister on taking a firm position and supporting the community which does not want anyone who is not a citizen of this country and who has been guilty of a criminal offence to have the opportunity to re-enter organised crime and the drug trade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the amendment proposed by my colleague, the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young). I have sat here and listened to this debate. A number of issues have been raised that really are not relevant to the two cases that we are looking at. I confine my remarks to the Pochi case because it is the case that I know most about. I have been involved in this matter since I was elected as the member for Canberra. I know that my predecessor, Mr Haslem, was involved in making representations on behalf of the family before I won the seat. Unlike many of the people who have spoken here today and given their views, judgments and assessments of the Pochi family, I have met and spoken to this family. I make an assessment, as the member representing them in this Parliament, of what I believe is in the best interests of Australia. My assessment of this case is that it is not in the best interests of Australia to break up this family, to send Mr Pochi back to the country where he was born but where he has no relatives and no ties. His ties now are with his new country and his family who are all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt and no debate that Mr Pochi committed a crime. I do not condone, and as no member on this side of the House and I am sure no member on the Government benches would condone, that behaviour. But that man has paid his price. He was convicted and served one year in gaol. Since 1975 he has gone through three courts of appeal which have come out in his favour. Judgments have been made in his favour. It was the judgment of the law that that man serve his sentence and that, although he was not an Australian citizen, he still had the right to remain in Australia. Yet the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee), a Minister for whom I, like other members of the Opposition, have a great deal of respect, has brought down a decision today that that man must be deported and his family broken up. I hope that when the Minister replies he will be able to give this House additional information on the reasons for the deportation because, frankly, I cannot see them in the statement he has submitted to this House or in the material that I have read in relation to this case. It seems to me that the basic reason Mr Pochi is being deported is that it has been found in the Minister's view to be against the interests of Australia for this man to remain in Australia.

Let me tell the House a little bit about Mr Pochi's family. My colleague, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Fry), told the House some of the personal aspects of this matter. I just want to reiterate them briefly as I know them. Mrs Pochi works in an office adjacent to my electoral office. I would see her probably on a weekly basis just as a working woman in my electorate. I have seen some of the children. They are hardworking kids who have often had to work part- time to try to help pay for the additional financial burdens that have been imposed on that family because of the court cases that they have had to fight. It has cost the family about $30,000, it has cost them their home and it has meant incredible hardship. A lot of obvious pressure has been placed on the family. I believe that over the last few years the family has done no harm to the Canberra community. As I said earlier, I know that the father of the family committed a crime and I believe he has paid for that crime.

The basic question is whether the continuing existence of that man in Australia is a threat to the future of this country. Some statements have been made, in particular by the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), about organised crime in Australia. I deplore organised crime just as do the honourable member for Boothby and my colleagues in this place. But I cannot believe with the personal knowledge I have of this family and that man, and on the evidence that I have read in transcripts of the appeals to the High Court and to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, that that man is the centre or even part of organised crime in Australia. I hope the Minister will be able to give me additional information on that. I am not just giving an emotional reply on this matter and I suppose I could be forgiven if I have. I know that the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) would forgive me as he forgave my colleague the honourable member for Fraser. I conclude by reading a statement that is not mine but that of Justice Brennan. The first point I want to raise is that Justice Brennan had before him evidence from a detective which provided information on what was going to emerge from the findings of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking. Justice Brennan concludes from that evidence:

But the evidence given in camera before me did not live up to expectations in that it lacked the cogency which would support a finding of fact against the applicant. In part that evidence was hearsay, and hearsay inevitably lacks the cogency inherent in evidence given by a person who has personal knowledge of the facts to which he deposes.
He concludes:

In this case, it is certain that deportation of the applicant would destroy or gravely damage a growing Australian family, and that would be a grave detriment not only to them but to Australia. His deportation, separating him from his Australian wife and children or requiring them to accompany him to a country that the children do not know, would be destructive of their prospects in life as well as his. Such a consequence is not justified by evidence-
I repeat the words 'not justified by evidence'-
which fails to prove that he was engaged in trading in marihuana, but which raises only a suspicion that he was so engaged.

Can my colleagues who are sitting opposite me in this chamber today truly, and in all conscience, from the knowledge they have of the case and from the time that they have put into examining the case, make an assessment that this man is a threat to the future of Australia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falconer Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment on some of the aspects of the debate that have risen this afternoon in this House. I do not want to comment specifically on the merits of the cases before us, especially the case of Mr Pochi, which has been quoted at some length by a number of honourable members who have participated in the debate. Firstly I want to compliment the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young), who led for the Opposition, on the way in which he responded to the statement of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee). He put a different point of view, but it was a view that ought to be expressed in a debate of this nature.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has exercised a discretion available to him under the Act which he was required to exercise and I think it is the sort of discretion which ought to be the subject of review by this chamber. So I think the honourable member for Port Adelaide approached this matter in a very responsible and moderate way and that this ought to be acknowledged by the House. I am disappointed that the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Charles Jones) has not participated in the debate because he made it clear by way of interjection that he disagreed with the approach being taken by the Opposition. I had the clear impression from the comments he made by way of interjection that he agreed with the decision that the Minister had reached. So if there is time for him to participate I would like to hear what he has to say on the subject because that would ensure that this matter is fully reviewed by this House.

I want to speak in more detail about one or two comments made by other honourable members. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) said that the Minister should stay his hand and allow the subject to be looked at in further detail. The fact is that I am aware that the Minister has been exercising his mind on this subject for many months. Indeed, we ought to acknowledge, as I have already said, that the legislation is framed in a way that allows the Minister a discretion to reject a recommendation of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal if he feels there are sufficient grounds for him to do so. I think we ought to dwell on that point because if the Minister has a discretion which is vested in him by both Houses of this Parliament we ought not automatically say that because the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has made a recommendation in a certain direction that Minister ought to accept that recommendation without question. He has, by virtue of legislation of this Parliament, a responsibility imposed upon him to review the decision or the recommendation of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and to see whether there are other grounds, other factors, which he should take into consideration in reaching a decision about whether to deport.

I think a point in that respect has been overlooked by many honourable members who have participated in this debate. The Minister in his opening statement pointed out that the report of the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, better known as the Woodward report, was not available at the time the Administrative Appeals Tribunal reviewed a previous decision of the Minister 's predecessor, the previous Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Indeed , since the report of the Woodward Commission has been available, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has in two cases referred to the findings of that report in the course of upholding decisions to deport people. That is a very important point.

At the time Mr Justice Brennan reviewed this matter in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal a very basic document which the Minister has available to him was not available to the Tribunal. I suggest very strongly to this House that when the Minister has vested in him a responsibility to exercise discretion he has to take into account not only the recommendation of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal but also any further evidence or information that is made available to him. I suggest that if he did not take account of the findings of a royal commission there would be very real grounds for members of this House to criticise him for not having taken adequate notice of such information at the time he made his decision to deport.

I also comment on something the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Fry) had to say. He said that the Pochi case-he referred specifically to that case-had been upheld on a number of occasions in the courts. He referred specifically to the High Court. I think it ought to be emphasised very strongly that anything the High Court had to say did not relate to the substance of the case-to the facts of the case-but to a legal point that had been brought to the High Court. The High Court stated that the Minister was not required to accept as correct any views as to the facts or as to the weight of evidentiary material expressed by the Tribunal. The High Court refused leave to appeal. It did not do that on the basis of an assessment of the facts of the case before it. It did not review the evidence of the case. What it did was state that the Minister in any event is not compelled to accept the recommendation of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; in fact, he has a discretion under the Act which he is fully competent to exercise; therefore, in effect, there is no real point in the High Court reviewing the decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I think that fallacious aspect of the argument put forward by the honourable member for Fraser should be noted and should be nailed very strongly. The High Court did not review the case. It did not find in favour of Mr Pochi in any substantial sense. It found that there was no need for it to review the recommendation of the Tribunal because, in fact, the Minister had available to him a discretion to decide in a direction other than the direction of the recommendation of the Tribunal if he so wished and if he had further information available to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cass The Hon M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Minister, when you became the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, as I at that time was the shadow Minister responsible for immigration and ethnic affairs on this side of the House, we had occasion to have quiet chats on a number of issues of some significance. Despite the surroundings here, which are not very personal, I would like to try to conduct this discussion between you and me. You will remember that we did have a talk about the practice, which had been pursued until you became the Minister, of deporting people who had been imprisoned for crimes committed in this country . They were deported after they had served their sentences. Despite the fact that we acknowledged that perhaps one could gain political capital out of pursuing that line because one could argue that we ought to be rid of criminals- there has been a hint of that sort of argument in some of the discussion this afternoon-we agreed that the penalty of being committed to gaol was enough. We agreed that the choices before you were either to deport someone found guilty of a crime or, alternatively, to put that person in gaol. We agreed that once that person had served the gaol sentence that was the end of it, that that person had paid his debt to society, such as we see it, like everybody else, and that that person should not face any further hazards.

SPEECH.PARA: I further remind you, Mr Minister, that in making these comments I am acknowledging that we have a problem. A couple of times I had occasion to talk to you about information that had come my way. I could have used that information to make political capital for my side of the House, but I chose not to do so because I felt that we had a problem. I will treasure the letter you sent to me acknowledging the help I gave on one of those occasions. You acknowledged that the help I and my staff had given and were able to give because of our contacts in the ethnic community had in fact helped you and your Department finally to nail a criminal organisation. I make that point because what I now wish to say is at that sort of personal level.

We have a problem. In your statement, Mr Minister, you have acknowledged that these people, found guilty of a crime of whatever it was, were held in gaol and presumably paid for that crime. That is not what the problem is about now. It is not about whether they were guilty of a crime and whether they have been sufficiently punished. The issue now is whether they belong to a secret organisation, and whether, as members of that secret organisation, they are involved in lots of things which obviously society does not like. Of course, that is not the only secret organisation of which we are aware. Some organsiations, which are not all that secret, indulge in all sorts of anti- social behaviour. The solution to the problem with this man or with anybody belonging to any of those other organisations that are not seen as based overseas is not to deport. If this man had been an Australian citizen you could not have deported him. It is purely an accident that he is still not an Australian citizen.

Before I move on to a further aspect of that, given that you are acting partly on the suspicion that that man is a member of this secret organisation and that you have listed some of the crimes, including the possible murder of Mr Mackay, it seems odd that you should be contemplating deporting him. I know from experience of cases of people being deported and of our subsequently having discovered that those people may have had evidence that would have helped in an investigation. I can call to mind one such case, but I will not specify it in the House. I am sure you recall it, Mr Minister. It was a case of someone who was prepared to sign and in fact signed a statutory declaration. We deported that person and, regrettably, then could not use him-I think it was a male-for the purpose of further investigation of a crime which I am convinced and you are convinced is being committed. I do not know how far you have got on that because I have not been in touch with you on this matter since then. It seems to me that as a result of the coroner's inquiry there may well be a possibility of the matter of Mackay's disappearance being pursued. If one or both of these people are associated with the organisation that is held to be responsible, it strikes me that it is not wise to deport them at this stage.

Having said that-I take that as a slightly opportunist point-I come now to the heart of what worries me. It is only a suspicion that these men belong to this organisation; it has not actually been proved. That is the first doubt that must weigh on your heart, Mr Minister. Next, even if they are members, as I have said , that is not the only secret organisation conducting criminal activities in this country. For all the other organisations the choice of deportation is not there; it is not a solution. If we find that someone belongs to one of those organisations, we still have to prove that that person belongs to it and that he in fact has done something of a criminal nature. If that is proved the penalty has to be a prison sentence, not deportation. But we do not have proof that these people, without any shadow of doubt belong to this secret organisation. We have no proof that the secret organisation in fact has done these things. Everybody has his suspicion and I share that suspicion.

On those grounds, Mr Minister, I think you-not the Government, but you-in your heart are facing a dilemma. I think you will come to regret the decision which it would appear you have made. I do not believe that on that suspicion sending these people out of the country will solve for us the problem of that secret society or perhaps the crimes that have been committed. One thing is certain and that is that by making this decision we are instrumental in damaging the families of these people. Surely the members of these families should not be held responsible for the actions of the father and husband, at least in respect of one case; I do not know enough of the details of the other case. I reiterate that deporting these people will not solve the problem that is basically confronting us. I do not know what will be the outcome of the inquires that are going on into the whole drug business and I do not want to enter into the arguments for and against drug trafficking. I have views which are different from many which have been expressed in this House, but that is irrelevant. I just do not believe that, in his heart, the Minister will rest content in making this decision in the light of the doubt that exists. I think the persons concerned are entitled to the benefit of the doubt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MACPHEE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I would like to thank all honourable members for their constructive and concerned contributions to this debate. I can assure the House that I have already taken into account each of the specific points which have been raised and also many of those which have been alluded to in the debate, and I include in that all the references to considerations of natural justice and the various arguments which were advanced by several speakers.

SPEECH.PARA: I would particularly like to say to the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Dr Cass) that I understand exactly how he feels. We did have that relationship of which he spoke and it has continued between his successor and myself. I believe, frankly, that Australia has benefited from the capacity which we have to sit down and discuss these matters of mutual concern. It is certainly true that there are proceedings before a court in Sydney at the moment which are the result of information given to me by the honourable member for Maribyrnong which enabled the police and the departmental officials to get to the bottom of a very serious immigration racket. I might also say that there are other members of the Opposition, not just in this House but in the Senate as well, who have co- operated with me in the same way, and I am most indebted to them. I think there are really no political points to be made in this sort of area. Certainly it has never been in my mind, although there was a suggestion from at least one speaker , that this matter had some political relevance. I do not think anyone else took the suggestion seriously. It certainly does not have political relevance.

It is true, as the honourable member for Maribyrnong has said, that he and I have discussed many issues, including the practice of deportation. I have had very healthy discussions with the Department about that and there is a division of opinion about the relevance of deportation on some occasions. I think on occasions it has the effect of being a double penalty. On other occasions I believe that it is appropriate. I believe it is appropriate in these cases for reasons which I shall refer to again in a moment. Recently I had discussions with the New South Wales Minister responsible for the criminal institutions, Mr Jackson, at his request and we have worked out an arrangement whereby he will on occasions release people for the purposes of deportation well before they have finished serving their sentences. I hope that that will be a practice we can adopt in other States, on which can be adopted for Commonwealth offences and one which therefore mitigates the occurrances when it can have the effect of being a double penalty. I say the effect of it because it is not, of course, the theory behind it. I think the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) said that my decision was a practical one. It is certainly a pragmatic one. It is based upon what Mr Justice Smithers has called reasonable suspicions which go well beyond the references which the honourable member for Maribyrnong made, but I understand his view.

In essence, I am satisfied that there does exist an organisation concerned with the cultivation and marketing of drugs and that Messrs Pochi and Barbaro are members of that organisation. I believe that I would be naive if I did not expect them to continue to be so. That is where the aspect of public interest comes into their deportation. The activities of that organisation are contrary to the interests of the Australian public and they outweigh the undeniably serious harm which will result to the private interests of the two families concerned. Their membership of the organisation is contrary to the interests of the Australian people and justifies their removal from the Australian society. It really is irrelevant that some other persons who are also members of the organisation cannot be deported by virtue of the fact that they are citizens.

Of course it was not an easy decision to reach. One thing that I want to repeat to the House is a point made in my opening remarks and by the honourable member for Casey (Mr Falconer) as well, but obviously not fully grasped by some members of the Opposition, and that is that the Woodward report was not before Mr Justice Brennan. The honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) and the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) both quoted Mr Justice Brennan as though he had before him that report and the honourable member for Kalgoorlie ( Mr Campbell) positively asserted that Mr Justice Brennan did have it before him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that he had the substance, and he did-in camera evidence.

—Hansard will record that the honourable member said quite categorically by interjection to the honourable member for Boothby that he had it. In any event, the fact is that he did not have the Woodward report before him and the learned judge chose to take a view of the role of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. But what is very clear is that the role of the Minister at least is not fettered strictly by the laws of evidence and the probity of material. I remind the House of what I said in my opening remarks, which was as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The High Court said that the Minister is not required to accept as correct any views as to the facts or as to the weight of evidentiary material expressed by the Tribunal. Thus it is clear that the Minister is entitled to make up his own mind as to the weight he gives to the material before him and that he may take into account and make his decision on the basis of matters which the Tribunal did not think to be sufficiently established before it.
That is what I have done.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to live with it then.

—I have to live with it, and I accept the fact that I have to live with it. As the honourable member for Casey has said, this Parliament has obliged me to make a decision. It is not a decision taken with a stroke of the pen, as the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Fry) has suggested. He also observed that it had taken me three months longer than I had hoped it would take me to reach a decision and that, frankly, was because of the number of times I looked at the file, put it away, mulled over it and looked at it again. I would say that in the past two years in looking at all of these drug related Administrative Appeals Tribunal deportation cases, including the Pochi and Barbaro ones, I must have spent personally hundreds of hours quite apart from the time of the officials. So the decision is certainly not one that has been taken with a stroke of the pen. It is a decision which, nonethless, I believe is a correct one. It was not a decision for this Parliament. It was appropriate that it be aired in this Parliament, but it was a decision which the Parliament had given to me to make. It was never a decision of Cabinet. One honourable member suggested that it was in fact a decision imposed upon me by Cabinet. It has never been discussed in Cabinet. It was my decision alone.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that one is balancing public and private interests and in my view, as I have said in my statement, the public interests on this occasion outweigh the private interests which have been the particular concern of those honourable members who have spoken against my decision. I repeat that if I were in their situation and had not spent the length of time I have spent on these matters I might well be at least expressing my remarks in the way that the honourable member for Port Adelaide has done. But in fact, having spent the time I have spent on it, I am convinced that my decision is correct.

Having reached the decision that I have on the material before me in accordance with what the High Court has said, and what the Act clearly states, I do not find any great difficulty in relying upon what might be an administrative error regarding the application for citizenship. The bigger decision was as to whether deportation was appropriate. When one decided that it was, by comparison the other decision was really not a major one.

The honourable member for Fraser (Mr Fry) spoke of possible legal proceedings. If there are to be any-and I would not be surprised if there were-my decision and the entire file, with my reasons stated therein, will be open to scrutiny by the appropriate court-as too will be the hearsay assertions advanced on behalf of Mr Pochi by the honourable member for Fraser. I remind the House that, if those proceedings are undertaken, the cooling-off period which has been referred to will certainly be available, but in order to found any other legal proceedings a decision has first to be made.

I make one other point in relation to that. A report in this morning's Canberra Times suggested that the Department had given the Pochis 72 hours in which to leave the country. That is not so. It is normal to ask people, when they are told that they are to be deported, to let the Department know their plans for departure. I would never have contemplated asking people who had been here for the time that the Pochis have been here to consider departing in 72 hours. I think it reasonable that they inform us what plans Mr Pochi, at least, is making for his departure. One would expect that any reasonable time that they asked for thereafter would be granted.

My final observation is to remind the House of my opening remarks regarding why I brought the matter before honourable members. I regard the public interest in the relationship of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Executive as of the utmost importance. To some extent it has been alluded to by honourable members in acknowledging its importance. Nevertheless, the debate has tended to focus on the personal case of Mr Pochi rather than the really significant principles underlying the relationship of the Tribunal to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I have taken into account all of the matters raised by honourable members. I am convinced that my decision is the appropriate one.
