DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Speaker has received letters from the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) and the honourable member for Eden- Monaro (Mr Sainsbury) proposing that definite matters of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion today. As required by Standing Order 107, Mr Speaker has selected the matter which in his opinion is the most urgent and important; that is, that proposed by the honourable member for Bonython, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The mounting costs, the growing confusion, and the increasing inequity of the present health scheme.
I therefore call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The latest Fraser health scheme is now five months old and we can make the first assessment of the rents and cracks that are appearing in it. The costs are clearly accelerating despite all the talk of cost constraint. The confusion is growing, particularly where we predicted it would grow, that is, the provision of cards for the disadvantaged. The ramshackle structure becomes more inequitable with each day that passes, primarily because of the increasing costs falling on individuals.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me take costs first. On 1 September, as a result of Commonwealth Government policies, the States were compelled to raise their basic rate hospital bed charges by 60 per cent from $50 a day to $80 a day, in most cases-a quite massive increase in charges. Barely three months under this new scheme had passed when the Government of New South Wales, as a result of increases in nurses' salaries, was compelled to make a further large increase-a 20 per cent rise in bed charges, to $96 a day.

The response of the Federal Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) to these decisions of the New South Wales Government is illuminating. Firstly, he accused the New South Wales Labor Government of electioneering, in not providing in its pre-election Budget for the rise in nurses' salaries. I want to know from the Minister today, and I hope I get a response, whether he will accuse every Liberal Premier-now desperately staving off further rises in hospital charges until he gets his election out of the way-of electioneering when, later in the year, he too will be forced to raise charges?

He then accused the New South Wales Government of having little regard for the effect of its decision on the cost of insurance. Again I ask him whether he will accuse the Liberal State governments of a similar disregard when inevitably in the coming months their hospital bed charges are raised. Finally, the Minister huffed and puffed about the responsibilities of the Commonwealth Government in the area of health insurance and its keenness to keep health insurance available at reasonable cost. But what did he do? The Minister, in fact, acquiesced in the rise in hospital bed charges in New South Wales. Indeed, he formally approved them. Now, as a result, he has approved the consequential rises of between $1.20 a week and $1.50 a week in health insurance charges in New South Wales.

I have dealt with this response in detail because the lesson of this story is that the Minister has simply lost control of hospital charges in this country, yet remains responsible for the insurance increases that flow from them. That is the dilemma with which the Federal Government is now faced. It cannot control hospital bed day charges effectively, yet remains in control of the health insurance system and will receive the blame for the increases that follow. Indeed, the activities in some of the State treasuries now must certainly be alarming the Minister. Twelve months ago we warned the Minister, as did the Jamison Committee, that to abdicate responsibility for hospitals, to divorce responsibility for hospital charges from responsibility for health insurance would lead to disaster. I think that the Minister and the Government, in their latest scheme, are now upon that slippery slope that will lead to the extinction of the fifth experiment in health insurance by this Government. The flow-on of increases in nurses' salaries will inevitably affect hospital bed charges in other States besides New South Wales, as will other efforts by the State governments to use hospital charges to deal with their own budgetary problems. For instance, it was announced this morning that Victoria is clearly considering rises occurring prior to the increase in nurses' salaries taking place. No doubt there will have to be increases afterwards. Mr Borthwick implied quite clearly this morning that his Government is already contemplating the raising of hospital bed day charges. There will be further rises in doctors' fees before the end of the year. The competitive pressure noted by the Opposition four or five months ago, to keep contribution rates down, so that the health insurance funds could attract as many new members as possible, is already beginning to affect the reserves of those funds. Thus, health insurance rates are bound to rise this year, well in advance of the rate of inflation. A conservative estimate-this is a conservative estimate; most of our estimates last year were conservative and proved to be accurate-is that by the end of the year, basic health contribution rates will average $12 a week per family, across the nation. I stress that that is a minimum estimate of average figures for the end of the year.

So it is already clear that the latest charges are useless as cost containment measures. They might save the Government some money, although even that is becoming increasingly dubious, but clearly they are leading to an escalation of health costs to the community. Moreover, the latest changes made to the health scheme on 1 September have directly fed inflation and inflationary expectations flowing from the consumer price index increases. Over one-third of the December CPI increase stemmed from changes to the health scheme. That 1.3 per cent increase attributed to the health area in the December CPI was almost twice the level predicted by the Government in the Budget papers. So much for the credibility of this Government. There is no need to worry about Government comments on any health figures because it cannot even get its own figures right. The Government predicted a three and a quarter per cent impact and it got 1.3 per cent impact.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you scared of? Come on.

—That is the cost problem and we will return to that in a moment. We will give the Minister his opportunity. I now turn to the bureaucratic morass around the health care cards. We predicted there would be problems. The scheme has been going for five months and at the moment only about one-third of those whom we were told would be eligible have been granted cards. The latest figures I have are for 12 February 1982, when the estimated number of accepted claims totalled 170,000. The Minister told us some five months ago that it was anticipated that some 460,000 individuals would be eligible to make claims for these cards. So, after five months, we are running well behind the eligible level of claims for health cards.

SPEECH.PARA: I think, too, that every honourable member in this House can tell stories- horror stories-about the problems ranging around these cards. I refer to one such problem I have encountered this week. We all know that the income level neces- sary to be eligible for a health care card, for a couple, was raised on 1 November from $160 to $165 a week. However, this rise is deceptive as the increase is only partially indexed. In the long run eligibility for the card will decline if partial indexation for the card continues as provided for in the amending Act; that is, fewer and fewer people will be eligible for the card while this system of indexation continues. Fewer people will be eligible for the card at the end of 1982 than at the beginning of the year. The confusion over entitlement to the card is compounded by the department that issues the card. I know that, in a sense, the Minister for Health is not really responsible for the Department of Social Security; no doubt he has enough problems in his own Department. Let us look at problems arising in the Department of Social Security . I refer to a form letter sent out to claimants for the card. It states:

Your present health care card tells you how much income you are allowed to have during any four weeks before you lose your eligibility to the card. From 1 November 1981 this four weekly amount of income has been increased to the value shown below.

What is shown below is, for a married couple, an amount of $825 per four weeks; that is, $206.25 a week. I would not blame somebody who received this letter for believing that the Government had suddenly been struck by extraordinary generosity and had raised the figure on 1 November from $160 to $206.25. That is what the letter appears to say. We here who know about the complex details of this measure know that that is simply a reference to temporary eligibility for the health card once a person has it. It has nothing to do with the level for initial eligibility and it has nothing to do with the continuation of the card after six months. It is simply a statement of what happens within the six month period so that a person does not lose the card. The constituent who received the letter to which I referred and no doubt many others simply believed that at these income levels one would be eligible to secure a health care card and continue to hold it at the end of the six-month period.

It seems to me that the very least the Government can do is to explain lucidly and simply the complexities of the scheme and stop putting out clearly misleading information such as this which any ordinary, intelligent elector could not but perceive was a statement that eligibility had been raised to $206. 25 a week, when we know that eligibility, for a couple, is $165 a week.

The increasing values of both the pensioner health benefit card and the health care card are forcing people into even more desperate ploys in order to retain them. Given that the loss of the card compels a couple to a minimum of $10 a week for basic health insurance payments the desperation of these people is understandable. Indeed, the health care card, coupled with a notch effect-that is, an arbitrary single cut-off point for eligibility-may well act as a poverty trap, discouraging the pursuit of extra earnings for fear of the risks involved.

Finally on the critical side, the inequity of the present arrangements stemming from the payment of flat rate money contributions for health insurance, unrelated to income and paid by all except the very poor needs no further stressing. It should be noted that as flat rate money contributions rise inexorably, as they will do this year, that inequity is simply compounded, as it will be through the rest of this year.

The Australian Labor Party has announced an alternative to the present medi- muddle. Firstly, it is obvious and little questioned by anyone that tying payments for health cover to income is a fairer way of providing health cover than flat rate money payments. Secondly, no one doubts that universality will be guaranteed through the operation of the health levy. Thirdly, there seems general agreement that the Labor plan is simpler than the present complex plan- not that that would be difficult; I do not make great claims that we have managed to achieve anything particular in that respect. Fourthly, the income- related levy will minimise if not completely eliminate the problems around the cut-off points for pensioner health benefit cards and health care cards. It may not completely eliminate all the problems but it will go a long way towards minimising them. Finally, the scheme announced by the Labor Party provides much more effective instruments for cost constraint if governments are prepared to use them.

The only serious criticisms advanced relate to the costing of the Labor plan. The costings have been carefully worked over by experts both within and outside the Labor Party and we are confident of their accuracy. I seek the leave of the House to have incorporated in Hansard a detailed breakdown of the costing of both the outlay and revenue sides of the plan. We have tried to indicate to the House the source of all those figures. Most of them are Government figures, and of course we have had to rely on their accuracy. TALK.START.PARA: —The specific criticism of the costing is that the 0.75 per cent levy on taxable income is pitched too low. The related question is also asked: Why is the health levy distinctly lower than that contemplated for the original Medibank? The general answer is that just as health insurance today does not cover the full cost of the provision of health care but simply that which is left over after all the subsidies have been allowed for, so the health levy is designed simply to fill the gap that remains on the revenue side once the extensive subsidies in the system already have been fully utilised. The beat-up front page story of the Australian simply discredited those experts who failed to make that kind of distinction.
—The levy will make up the difference?
—It will make up the difference.
—No matter what the difference is?

—I will deal with that now. We do not intend to take away any of the extensive subsidies already in the system. We intend to rearrange them in a more efficient, more direct and more equitable way. This rearrangement permits us to have a relatively low levy and to reduce the direct weekly costs for additional private insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem of the proposed levy being lower than that of the original Medibank has been raised, but the answer is simply that the subsidies in the system are now far greater than pre-1974. I will list four of those major extra subsidies. Firstly, prior to Medibank 1 the pensioner benefit was only 60 per cent of fees and did not apply to private specialists. The moneys for 85 per cent cover and specialist cover for pensioners-an increase of at least $200m on 1981-82 figures -are now in the system. Indeed, further moneys are there providing such cover for the disadvantaged. Secondly, the Commonwealth subsidy for medical insurance is more significant today than in pre-Medibank days. Thirdly, the tax rebate for health involves a significantly greater amount of forgone revenue than did the pre-Medibank tax deductibility system. Fourthly, and above all, the Commonwealth today, even this Government, is contributing much more to hospital costs than was the case pre-Medibank. Even this Government is meeting about 35 per cent of all public health costs compared with only 13 per cent in the pre- Medibank period. Taking into account the fact that the levy is combined with savings as set out in the document which has been tabled in the House, could I ask him whether, if those amounts do not reach the intended total, the levy be raised to cover the difference?

—And if it is not, will the levy be raised? That is the essential question.
—We are perfectly confident about the figures.
—Order! I think this has gone far enough. Please direct your questions through the Chair, Mr Minister.

—I can understand the honourable member's reticence in answering the question because it is one of tremendous significance. He has ducked for cover, as I would expect him to do, because it is the question which all the Australian people will be asking and it is something which naturally enough the Australian Labor Party will have to explain in the very near future. But once again we see the Opposition searching for some feasible line with which to criticise the Government's health scheme. I would say at this stage that this is a scheme which has been readily accepted by the people of Australia since its introduction on 1 September last year. I think it can be clearly seen that the scheme has been accepted by the fact that nearly all of the population of this country is protected in some form or other for health care.

SPEECH.PARA: I fully realise that the honourable member for Bonython has been running around the country trying to stir up discontent with the population over the Government 's health scheme. As recently as last week he was interviewed on the Australian Broadcasting Commission armed, as usual, with incorrect information, saying that up to two million Australians were not covered for health insurance. I should like to lay out the facts of the situation. As at 30 November 1981 over 70 per cent of the population had hospital insurance, with about 66 per cent of the population having medical insurance as well. The hospital insurance figure provides a better estimate for insurance coverage as a number of people would have chosen to take hospital only insurance, either because they have chosen to meet medical costs out of their own pocket, to receive medical treatment at an outpatients clinic and/or are happy with a hospital doctor should they require surgery. Over 20 per cent of the population is covered by the Commonwealth's free health arrangements which look after those in special need. Again we have this tired old argument trotted out by the honourable member for Bonython that the figures of those who have actually taken out the cards do not correspond with those who are eligible for the cards. The fact of the matter, as I have been putting forward time and time again, is that people do not have to take out those cards until it is necessary for them so to do. There is a retrospective element in the issuing of those cards which conveniently is forgotten always by the spokesman for the Labor Party.

Over one million people in Queensland, or about 7 per cent of the total population, have not taken out any insurance cover. The principal reason is that the State's traditional free public hospital system still operates. I should like honourable members to keep that point in mind when we have a closer look at a later stage at the modestly named Hayden health plan. I am sorry that it is not called the Blewett health plan because I acknowledge that he did most of the work involved. Nevertheless, he does not seem to rate too highly in the naming stakes.

A number of persons in New South Wales may not have insured because of the decision by that State Government to provide free public hospital treatment to certain categories of people. For example, over 100,000 pensioners who are not eligible for a pensioner health benefit card are covered by the New South Wales State Government arrangement. A number of these persons could be expected to have decided that health insurance was unnecessary for their purposes. Also, about one per cent of the population is covered by commercial insurance arrangements. So if we add all that up, it can clearly be seen that despite the propaganda emanating from the honourable member for Bonython, and other Labor Party spokesmen, there is no confusion in the minds of the public as to what the Government's health scheme is all about. In fact, one could make the observation that the only person who seems to be confused about the Government's health scheme is sitting opposite me at the present time.

As I mentioned in this House last year, and it is still true today, the attitude of the Australian Labor Party towards the Government's health scheme is , 'To blazes with the best interests of the people. Let us create confusion; let us try to convince people that something is complex,' when any calm, considered analysis of the arrangements would refute that suggestion.

The Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency of Hospital Administration highlighted considerable waste and inefficiency in the States' public hospital systems and identified a range of areas in which performance could be improved dramatically. That is a fact which the Opposition conveniently overlooks. In fact, the New South Wales Minister for Health, who is not a conservative, acknowledges that there is inefficiency. I quote from the Sydney Morning Herald of 13 February this year:
If we just run around in circles and approach the problems by tipping the usual bucket on Canberra, while not doing everything we can to get our own house in order, we are bound to fail.
Here is at least one Labor Party Minister acknowledging that there is a great deal to do in order to clean up the inefficiencies which exist in State government situations.

The inquiry also pointed out that there is an oversupply of hospital beds, wasteful duplication of facilities, inappropriate geographic location of facilities, an apparent lack of sound management principles and that some hospital administrators and State governments do not exercise proper control over expenditure. Significantly, from the Commonwealth's point of view, it found that the divided responsibility between the Commonwealth and the State governments arising from the hospital cost sharing agreements was a contributing factor. In the face of this evidence the Government could not just stand by and allow the then funding arrangements for State health services to continue. We could not allow taxpayers' funds to be used to underwrite waste and inefficiency . We therefore undertook a thorough review of those arrangements. That review culminated in my statement to Parliament in April last year in which I announced a number of major changes to the present health financing arrangements.

These changes have resulted in full constitutional responsibility for the provision of health services and for determining priorities for the allocation of funds to the different parts of the health system being returned to the States. They have resulted in all Australians becoming more responsible for their own health care needs and lifestyle and more aware of the full cost of the health services available to them. They have resulted in special assistance being available only to those in special need. They have resulted in people in the community who can pay their own way contributing to the cost of their health care. They have resulted in health insurance being available to all at a reasonable cost and on a community rating basis. In fact, health insurance today is cheaper than at the same time last year, once the tax rebate of 32c in the dollar is taken into account. Again the honourable member for Bonython always fails to acknowledge that point.

These changes have also resulted in the Government offering general assistance towards health care costs only to those who are willing to help themselves by taking out health insurance. They stress the important role of the private sector in the health care system being fully recognised and providers of health care services becoming more aware of the costs which they generate. Finally, they have resulted in a slowing in the rise in the costs of health care and the health cost burden of the general community. I find it somewhat difficult to understand how those on the Opposition side can complain about mounting costs, given their performance in the Whitlam years. Total health care costs rose substantially in the Labor years of government. The only substantial halt to the cost increases came with the advent of this Government. I quote the figures. In 1972-73 total health care costs were $2,505m; for 1973-74 the figure was $3,012m an increase of 20.2 per cent; for 1974-75 the figure was up 37.7 per cent; and for 1975-76, it was up 35.1 per cent. Then this Government came into power and the figure decreased to 14.7 per cent. In 1977-78 the figure decreased to 13.1 per cent and in 1978-79, 9.8 per cent. A similar pattern applies to gross operating costs of public hospitals. The dangers of a reintroduction of a recycled Medibank under the guise of the Hayden plan are clearly evident for Australian taxpayers, given that record of cost increases.

The Government's political opponents have been attempting to claim that the new health policy will limit people's access to health care because some individuals will not have sufficient income to pay for health services or take out insurance , that somehow the Government's arrangements are inequitable. This claim is patently incorrect. As part of the Government's aim of ensuring that all Australians have proper access to high quality health care, it has decided to introduce special assistance arrangements to help those in genuine need. It is claimed by the Labor Party and some academics who should know better, that the Government's health policy is inequitable as all people who insure pay the same premium, irrespective of their income. We have heard that cry frequently from the honourable member for Bonython. What he and those critics fail to acknowledge is that people on high incomes will bear a larger burden of the cost of government assistance in the health area than people on lower incomes. This is because the Government's subsidies provided for health are financed through the taxation system, so those on higher incomes are already paying more towards financing the health care.

The honourable member for Bonython has made a great deal of noise about the costs to the individual of the Government's health scheme. Once again, I feel it incumbent upon me to advise him of the facts. The Government has recognised that for community rated health insurance to operate effectively it is important that insurance contributions should be set at levels that most people in the community can afford to pay. With this in mind and with the objective of assisting those willing to assist themselves, the Government decided that contributions for basic hospital and medical insurance with registered health insurers would attract a tax rebate of 32c in the dollar; that Commonwealth medical benefits be restricted to those people who have at least basic medical cover with a registered insurer and be payable at a flat rate of 30 per cent of the scheduled medical fees; and that the Government's payment to assist health insurers to pay hospital benefits for the chronically ill be set at $100m this year.

The Government's critics claim that a principal aim of the new health policy, namely, the containment of health costs, will not be achieved-we have heard that today-principally because that policy promotes the use of services provided by the private sector of the health care delivery system. That claim basically amounts to a criticism of 'fee-for-service' payment arrangements and the operation of private hospitals. Put another way, it is an argument in favour of the expansion of the public sector of the health care delivery system. I think the honourable member for Bonython would agree that what he is essentially after is an expansion of the public sector at the expense of the private sector.

The Government recognises that any health care delivery system operating in Australia can be abused. Because we do recognise this, we have taken and will continue to take strong measures to prevent over-use and abuse of the health care delivery system. We have taken action to reduce the incidence of abuse by those few people in the health care professions who may seek to misuse or defraud the system for their own gain. A vigorous attack on medical fraud through collaboration between my Department, the Australian Federal Police and the Attorney-General's Department resulted in 22 successful prosecutions in 1981 and a further six cases are now before the courts. That effort will be sustained , and I would hope to see more people who deserve to come before the courts so coming before the courts and being charged and convicted. The medical profession had always held a high place in public esteem. Nonetheless those practitioners who abuse their position are now on notice that they will be vigorously pursued.

Since my original indication that the ALP costings for its proposal might be understated by as much as $150m, I have been provided with figures which quite frankly are so alarming in the extent to which they show that Labor has undercosted its plan, that I have asked that they be thoroughly re-checked by my Department. The costings I have seen so far make a mockery of the suggestion that the ALP could fund its plan through a 0.75 per cent levy. That is why I asked the question of the honourable member for Bonython, and that is why he refused to answer it. It would be a cruel deceit if the ALP were to try to convince the public that health care would be provided free or at a substantially reduced cost to the public. Without a massive injection of government funds, with its implications for taxation and inflation, the ALP plan would inevitably lead to increasing demand on the resources of the public hospital system-the most costly sector within the health care delivery system- thereby straining services to such an extent that access would be delayed or denied, people would need to queue for medical treatment, and those less able to meet the costs of services would need to compete with people better able to pay for private health services.

Labor's scheme provides no encouragement to the general community to accept greater personal responsibility for their health care costs through the user pays principle and by promoting bulk billing the Labor plan would facilitate fraud and over-servicing. Labor's plan would take back to the Commonwealth involvement in decisions such as on hospital standards. The incentives which this Government has provided through its policy for the States to effect efficiencies in their public hospital systems would be lost. Labor's plan ignores the tremendous contribution of general practice and its cost effectiveness. It has been clearly demonstrated that general practitioner consultations result in proportionately far fewer repeat consultations, referrals to specialists and so on than do consultations conducted in hospital outpatients and casualty departments.

Labor's plan is clearly hastily conceived and poorly thought through. No mention is made for instance, of the nursing home benefit for which the Government will be spending approximately $600m in 1981-82; and it is by no means clear on what is proposed in regard to separated people with dependants, Australian taxpayers overseas, servicemen and their families, veterans and their families and overseas visitors to Australia. It would be a disaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that either the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) is suffering from sleeping sickness or his Department is asleep because our policy has been out for something more than three weeks now and the Department has still not come up with the figures with which the Minister threatens us to show how inadequate our costing is. He is still just making the threats. If that is the way in which the Department functions under him, it is no wonder that the scheme is a mess.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister is disputing the number of uninsured people in the country. We claim that it is about two million, taking into account the people in New South Wales who are not insured-it does not matter for what reason-and likewise in Queensland, and there it seems to be in defiance of the Federal Government, with Queenslanders hell-bent on maintaining their free hospital system. The Minister says that there are many people who are automatically entitled, and of course that includes pensioners. They are in the 20 per cent that is the balance that we are claiming contains many people who are uninsured. But of course, the Minister does not take any notice of the fact that, sadly, an enormous proportion of pensioners take out insurance because they are fearful that if they get ill they will need to have the care which can be obtained only through private medical practice. So despite the fact that theoretically they do not need to take out cover, they do so. Therefore, we stick to our estimate that there is an uncomfortably large number of people in the community not insured.

As to be expected, the kneejerk reaction-that is a reaction without any cerebral effort, with no thought whatsoever-by the Liberal Government through the Minister and other members of the Goverment, and others no doubt, has been to make the most harrowing forecasts about the effects of Labor's health proposal. It was the same when we first proposed a national health scheme in 1968. We were greeted with cries of 'thin end of the socialist wedge', 'will send the country bankrupt', 'the neurotics will overload the medical profession when they do not have to pay anything under bulk billing', and 'no one really ill will ever be able to see a doctor', and similar hysterical nonsense. The answer to all that decerebrate rubbish was the response of the electorate in 1969, and through that response, the move by the then leader of the Liberal Government, Prime Minister Gorton, to introduce, in a ham-fisted way, the essence of at least one facet of our proposal-cover for the poor who had no cover under the voluntary health insurance system, and that is the situation now , too.

The way in which this was proposed to be overcome by Gorton was by introducing what was called the subsidised health benefits plan. It required the underprivileged to apply for cover under the scheme. That is the case today. By way of excuse, the Minister says, when we make the charge that many people who should be covered are not, that they do not have to apply for cover until they need it because then it will all be retrospective. The interesting question is, why do they not apply? The answer is, of course, that for a variety of reasons such as feelings of inadequacy, resentment of characterisation as underprivileged, lack of information or plain inability to comprehend the complexities of the system, only an insignificant proportion of the population which should have been covered was enrolled in the plan and enabled to have access to the services which we offered and ultimately, of course, automatically introduced as a right under Medibank. The same situation prevails today. One can say quite glibly that it will be retrospective when the need arises, but I am sure that that is not what people are feeling. They are feeling humiliated. They may well be forced to take advantage of the system when they have to, but that is no answer to the effect on them as individuals by virtue of this, in our view , unseemly pressure.

It is true that the cost of health care rose significantly in the 1970s, and again Labor was blamed without thought or recognition of the facts. Costs started to rise towards the end of the 1960s, standing at about 5.1 per cent of gross domestic product in 1968-69 and rising to 6.78 per cent of GDP in 1974-75. This was occurring before there were any changes to the basic system by Labor because Medibank was introduced in July 1975. I obtained those figures from reports of the Commonwealth Department of Health for 1974-75 and 1977-78. With the introduction of Medibank in July 1975 costs continued to rise in the same way and, after the destruction of Medibank by the Liberal Government, costs for health services to the whole community still continued to rise. Preliminary estimates for 1978-79-they are the latest figures available and they are still only preliminary estimates-indicate that we are now up to 7.5 per cent of GDP.

Medibank did not arrest the trend nor have the changes the Government has made. All that the changes to Medibank by the Liberal Government have achieved is an apparent reduction in the cost of health services to the Federal Government. By saying 'the Federal Government' one is implying 'the taxpayer' because there is less taxpayer revenue going via the Federal Government. But that in no way is a comfort to the average person. Along with the theoretical possibility of reduced taxes due to the reduced Commonwealth responsibility for health care costs there has been a significant direct increase in costs to the individual. Now we all must take out private health insurance cover, compared with Medibank days-that is, Medibank I. The contribution rates are inequitable in that they are independent of the indvidual's income. Thus we are back to the situation which existed before Medibank whereby the poor subsidise the rich for health services.

Tax reduction remains a theoretical possibility only. In fact, the burden of taxation has increased significantly for low income earners whilst it has reduced or at least stabilised for the rich. I am not blaming all that on the health services but in general terms I am making the point that the changes the Government has made to the health scheme, which supposedly were to reduce the cost, in fact have not meant a reduction in cost in terms of either the taxation people are paying or the actual out-of-pocket expenses for individuals in the community because all are expected to pay benefit contributions to the benefit funds. In the way it is done under the private health insurance system the poor, in essence, are slugged at a much greater rate than the rich.

With the population now divided into the underprivileged and the rest, with stringent assessment criteria being imposed on the poor to enable them to qualify for health care without having to pay contributions to private health funds, we have confusion heaped upon indignity for the less well-off in society. I am sure that no one in this chamber would like to have to expose himself to the embarrassment associated with seeking to establish one's needs and lack of resources under the present Liberal Government scheme to qualify for health care with no cost in terms of contributions to health funds. It is an insulting poorhouse approach which surely should not be imposed on anyone in this country in the 1980s.

I will return to the ostensible aim of the Liberal Government in changing Medibank, particulary the more recent changes. As I have said, the apparent aim was to reduce the cost to the Commonwealth, never mind the public. Even this deplorable aim has not been achieved. This is the reason we are able to propose a modest levy of 0.75 per cent on taxable income with generous exclusions for low income earners, particularly those with dependants, and we would be able to provide universal access for all to medical services with a rebate of 85 per cent of the fee if the doctor decides to bulk bill. If the doctor bulk bills the patient pays nothing and the doctor is satisfied with the 85 per cent. In any case, whether the doctor bulk bills or not, we would provide a maximum payment of $10 for any service.

Why is this possible? The Minister for Health questioned us about what we would do if the levy did not cover it. Let us look at what has happened under this Government. Let me elaborate on the matter of the Commonwealth contribution because this is the basis of our calculations. The Commonwealth, the Liberal Government, now puts in much more money than it used to in pre-Medibank days. A large part of of the additional cost of Medibank I, which had to be met from the then proposed 1.35 per cent levy, was due to a decision to increase pensioner benefits from 60 per cent to 85 per cent of fees and to extend these to specialist services because previously pensioners were covered for general practitioner services alone. No one would propose that we go back on that. The Liberal Government would not and we certainly would not. The cost of that was $ 200m, looking at it in 1981-82 values. In other words, it is not now necessary for us to find that money. It is there. The Liberals have retained the 85 per cent benefit and extended it to the disadvantaged.

In 1981-82 Commonwealth benefits will meet about 50 per cent of all insurable medical bills. In other words, we have to raise only about 38 per cent to replace the present private insurance benefits. Adding to that the tax concessions which we would give, not in the form of tax concessions which again favour the rich but in the form of direct benefits, that would cover easily the loss of revenue by reducing hospital charges to patients going into private hospitals or extending free treatment. The Commonwealth Government is now putting much more into hospitals via State grants than it did pre-Medibank, so again we would not have to raise those funds. The Government is already putting them in there. We are not suggesting that we would cut back on Commonwealth spending. We are simply saying how we could reorganise the present expenditure to fit in with our proposal and still fund it all with a modest 0.75 per cent levy. I am sure that when the Minister looks into it he will find that that is true.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to join this debate. It is an excellent opportunity to support the Government's initiatives of the last year and to comment upon the Australian Labor Party's policy recently announced. Australia spends approximately 8 per cent of its gross domestic product on health care. That is a proportion which has increased very greatly from the early 1970s. The expenditure of the Department of Health exceeded $3.25 billion last year. It is essential that public money of this kind be spent in an efficient and effective way.

SPEECH.PARA: In discussing the present scheme it is instructive to remember what existed before. For many years there was general concern about whether we were getting value for money in the health area. This concern grew as the proportion of the expenditure on health increased. This concern led to the establishment, amongst other things, of the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals. The Commission highlighted considerable waste and inefficiency in the States' public hospital systems and identified areas where performance could be improved dramatically. In particular it pointed to the over -supply of hospital beds, the duplication of facilities and the inappropriate geographic location of facilities. There was an apparent lack of sound management principles and there were some hospital administrators and State governments that did not exercise proper control over expenditure.

It is extraordinary that the Opposition should now bring on a matter of public importance alleging mounting expenditure when the previous inefficiencies arising from its own free spending past have been so thoroughly documented and condemned. The Commonwealth Government could not allow taxpayers' funds to be used to underwrite such waste and inefficiency. The Government, therefore, undertook a thorough review of the then existing arrangements and closely considered a number of options aimed at overcoming the problems revealed. This review was carried out within the context of the Government's overall health policy. The health care delivery system in this country is extremely complex and no one part of it can be considered separately.

One other matter included in the review was the relationship between Government financial assistance and the health insurance system. The combination of free public hospital treatment for all people irrespective of their income and the existing Commonwealth medical benefit arrangements had caused a gradual erosion of health fund membership. As a result of the community rating principle, whereby the burdens of ill health are shared through a common contribution rate, those most dependent upon health insurance-the aged, people with chronic illness and families with children-would have been seriously threatened had the Government permitted the trend away from community rated insurance to continue. Those people would certainly have had to pay much higher health insurance premiums.

Therefore, one of the Government's objectives was to establish an environment in which all Australians would become more responsible for their health care needs and more aware of the full cost of health services provided to them. When patients have to make a personal contribution, however small, for the health services they receive, they are likely to question doctors about the need for and the likely benefit of the procedure and treatment. Further, the Government recognised that, if those who could afford to pay were required to contribute towards their health costs, taxation could be lower than would otherwise be the case and Government financial assistance could be directed more towards those in genuine need.

Last April, the Government announced policies designed to achieve a number of objectives, including that all Australians should become more responsible for their health care needs and more aware of the full cost of the health services provided to them. The policies provided that special assistance be made available only to those in special need and that people in the community who could pay their way should be encouraged to do so. Health insurance was made available to all at a reasonable cost and on a community rated basis. It is interesting to note that the gloomy forecasts by the Opposition on the cost of health insurance in the event were proved quite wrong. Contribution rates for health insurance are at the lowest rate relative to average weekly earnings for approximately five years.

The success of these measures can readily be judged by the wide acceptance of the new arrangements throughout the community. On the information currently available, as the Minister has already indicated, well over 90 per cent of the population are now covered against health costs. Indeed, over 70 per cent have taken out private health insurance. The remaining 20 per cent are essentially covered by Government programs such as those for pensioners and those in special need.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about all the double counting and what about the pensioners?

—It is true that there are some people who have not yet taken out health cards. However, as the Minister has already pointed out, there is a 13- week period in which people can obtain a card once they have had some treatment.
—If they get three prescriptions the cost is $9.60. They cannot pay for it.

—I wish the interjection was relevant to the point I am making. The fact is that the vast proportion of the Australian populace is covered. The honourable member for Maribyrnong (Dr Cass) tried to suggest that those who have not taken out a health card have not done so because they may have been embarrassed about it. That seems a most unlikely explanation. There seems to be no reluctance on the part of those eligible for pensioner health benefit cards to take them out. It seems unlikely that persons of younger years would be any more embarrassed. The probability is that, knowing that they do not have to take out a card before they have treatment, they have simply not troubled to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite Opposition allegations of inequity, there is one area of spending in which the Government has a clear and unequivocal commitment; that is to the needy. We have maintained the protection now afforded to eligible pensioners and their dependants. They are eligible for free public hospital accommodation and treatment and for bulk billed medical services. The Government has guaranteed the same protection for all migrants and refugees during their first six months in Australia and for unemployed people, special beneficiaries and others who meet the income test. It is worth noting that that income test is a fair one, having regard to the current level of income earnings. The income limit of $165 a week for married couples is equal to almost 60 per cent of average weekly earnings. The allowance of $20 a week for each child is equal to approximately 7 per cent of average weekly earnings. For example, a married man with three children can earn $225 a week, which is almost 75 per cent of average weekly earnings on the latest figures, and still qualify for special assistance. I repeat: A man with a wife and three children and who earns 75 per cent of average weekly earnings will still qualify for special assistance. These eligibility levels are adjusted twice yearly.

When such cover is available, it is just not valid to allege inequity. The policies that we have implemented will ensure that those in special need are covered for health care, that the Government's expenditure on health care is well placed and that the overall goal of proper access to high quality health services at a cost that the individual can afford is achieved.

The fact is that the Opposition is still wedded to the concept of Medibank, a concept which has been demonstrated not to work. The Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals set that out chapter and verse, but most Australians already knew that Medibank just did not work. Uncontrolled expenditure did not help those who needed it most. Large sums were spent on those who could have helped themselves. Public funds were wasted. As the Minister has said, a cost explosion would happen if Labor's new policy were implemented. Mounting costs, growing confusion and increased inequity are terms which are not referable to the current scheme but are referable to Labour's proposal. If Labor's proposal were implemented, we would certainly see inequities and cost explosions. We are happily not seeing them at present.
