PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your Petitioners are gravely concerned by the proposed imposition of Sales Tax on items concerned with educational books, clothing, footwear, newspapers, buildings and food wrappings, as these sales taxes impose a further burden on home builders, families and children; inhibit the free flow of information through books and newspapers; and reduce employment opportunities.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in parliament assembled, should exempt these items from the proposed Sales Tax legislation, as requested by the Senate.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Everingham and Mr Moore.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the proposed imposition of Sales Tax on items concerned with home building, clothing, footwear, books and newspapers, wrapping for food.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament to exempt these items from the proposed Sales Tax as requested by the Senate to avoid such taxes on necessities of life becoming a further burden on home builders, families and children or inhibiting the free flow of information through books and newspapers or reducing employment opportunities for people in the industries concerned and beyond.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(a) that the Australian Government signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women in Copenhagen in 1980;
(b) that the Convention came into force on 3 September 1981;

(c) that Australian women suffer serious disadvantage in employment, education, accommodation, membership of licensed clubs, provision of goods and services including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans, credit or finance;

(d) that the disadvantage could be overcome by (i) making unlawful certain discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status, (ii) eliminating discrimination on the ground of sex and marital status and (iii) promoting affirmative action for women in employment;
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament pass the Sex and Marital Status Discrimination Bill 1981.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child and Mr Connolly.

PETITION.TITLE: Marie-France Claude
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Marie-France Claude is the Vice-President of the Christian Democrat Party of Haiti. The party is opposed to the government of President-for-Life Jean-Claude Duvalier, but it does not use or advocate violence. Because of her activities in the Christian Democrat Party, Marie-France Claude has been sentenced to fifteen years imprisonment with hard labour.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government pass on to the Haitian Government the concern of the undersigned citizens, and their wish that Marie-France Claude be released from prison.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Drummond and Mr Lloyd.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the decrease in Federal Government funding for health, transfer of Commonwealth responsibilty to the States, application of the 'user' pay principle to health services and encouragement of private business and profits in the health sphere will inevitably lead to a downgrading of health services and increasing health risks among people who cannot afford health insurance or private payment of doctors and hospitals.

That the cuts in Federal Government spending resulting from the recommendations of the Cabinet Sub-committee of Review of Government Functions (Razor Gang) will lead to an increase in unemployment and a general deterioration in community service and living standards.
Therefore your petitioners urge that:
1. The Government continue Commonwealth funding of health services at an improved, and certainly not a lesser, level than that operating prior to September 1, 1981.
2. That recommendations of the Cabinet Sub-committee of Review of Government Functions (Razor Gang) be not proceeded with.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Diabetics: Insulin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-

That in view of the recent standardisation of insulin and insulin syringes, having the effect of increasing the cost of both items to the Diabetic in general, and as every insulin-dependent diabetic must use the same, daily or twice daily according to medication.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that syringes be made available on the N .H.S. and that insulin prescriptions revert to 10 bottles as previously supplied .
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Australian Parliament assembled.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament assembled takes action as it deems appropriate;
a. to ensure that funding in the area of child care will not be cut or reduced.

b. to ensure that the Children's Service Programme Manual: Interpretation of the Child Care Act 1972-73 be altered to allow part time occasional care centres to be funded as it seems possible under the Act Section 4 (1) a.
c. to ensure that funds are allocated to half day occasional care centres which are meeting the needs of mothers who stay at home to care for their children.
Your petitioners, therefore humbly request that Parliament assembled take immediate and positive action on the above mentioned issues.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Toxoic Shock Syndrome
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned by the threats to women's health and lives posed by Toxic Shock Syndrome, and urge the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency: -

(1) Tampons, sanitary napkins, vaginal deodorants and similar sanitary products to be re-classified under Therapeutic Agents (not under ''Cosmetics'' as at present), in order to bring them under the scrutiny of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. We believe manufacture must be under the strictest hygienic conditions.

(2) After re-classification, we urge an immediate government-funded inquiry into all aspects of manufacture and content of these products. This must lead to : (i) contents of product and instructions for correct usage to be shown on packaging; (ii) removal of synthetic fibres, chemicals or ingredients that are potentially or actually harmful to users.

(3) Allocation of extra funding for ongoing research by the National Health and Medical Research Council into these products, results of this research to be made public to ensure all health workers and potential users are fully informed. This campaign of public education would necessitate multilingual distribution of the information where appropriate.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert possible threats posed to women's health by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Estate Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of effective Federal environmental protection legislation and urge that suitable legislation be enacted immediately.

Your petitioners are concerned that National Estate areas such as South West Tasmania, the Great Barrier Reef and the Western Australian Jarrah Forrests cannot be fully protected until adequate legislation exists and is enforced. Your humble petitioners therefore call upon the House of Representatives to ensure that all provisions of the Heritage Act and the Environment Impact of Proposals Act are fully complied with in respect of National Estate Areas. In particular your petitioners call upon you to adopt the recommendations of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment on South West Tasmania. Your petitioners believe that this is a national issue and must be resolved by the action of the Federal Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the projected repeal by the Queensland State Government of the Aborigines Act 1971-1979 and the Torres Strait Islander Act 1971-1979 will almost certainly lead to the degazettal of all Aboriginal reserves in Queensland, as has already been the case with Aurukun and Mornington Island.

That if, as is likely, the Aboriginal communities from these reserves are placed under similar shire council legislation on fifty year leases, they will be exposed to serious encroachment on their land by mining and tourist interests .

That it is also quite clear, on past evidence, that these interests will have the full backing of the Queensland government and the rights of Aboriginal people to land rights and self-management will not be granted by that Government .

That the Commonwealth Government has the power to legislate and acquire land for Aboriginal people under its constitutional powers since the amendments to the Constitution in 1967, but it is your Petitioners' sincere belief that it failed to act in 1978 and thus, failed in its duty before the people of Aurukun and Mornington Island.
That the Aboriginal people of Queensland have stated that they want land rights and self management.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government make use of its constitutional and legislative powers to grant full land rights and self-management to the Aboriginal people of Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Theatre in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your Petitioners are gravely concerned by proposed reduction in funds to Theatre in Australia. This will result in the reduction of the Theatre's contribution to the quality of civilised life, refinement and projection of national identity, and its contribution to tourism; and the reduction of employment opportunities in the Arts.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should support Theatre in Australia by increasing grants to a realistic level.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: St Francis Xavier High School, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-
That the pupils, teachers and parents are gravely concerned by the inadequate ventilation of St Francis Xavier High School at Florey in the Australian Capital Territory.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will appropriate the funds needed to rectify the problem in the 1982-83 Budget.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Immigration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizen showeth:
That we protest at breakdowns in our Restrictive Immigration policy which, many senior members of our parliament had vigorously supported in their past promises to the Australian people.
We urge the Government to accede, not only to the wishes of the majority, as expressed in all public opinion polls, but also to act in accordance with their own statements. For E.G.:
1. 'We want one Australian people, one Australian Nation.'-Mr McMahon.
2. 'The avoidance of difficult social problems following an influx of people having different standards of living.'-ALP policy 72.
3. 'I believe we should do all in our power to prevent the build up of ethnic groups within Australia.'-Mr MacKellar.

4. 'Our policies reflect the firm and unshakeable determination of the Government to maintain a homogeneous society, a society that is essentially undivided and free of avoidable tensions.'-Dr Forbes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern over Plant Variety Rights (PVR) legislation.
We agree that:
(1) PVR will aggravate the free exchange of genetic material for plant breeding .
(2) PVR will not enhance Australia's access to improved plant varieties developed overseas but will encourage the dumping of unsuitable varieties on the Australian market.
(3) PVR will restrict the public plant breeding program to basic research for exploitation by private enterprise and discourage breeding for disease and pest resistant varieties.
(4) PVR will lead to the domination of the seed industry by foreign interest not responsible to the Australian people.
(5) The proprietary rights granted by PVR will encourage the introduction of seed distribution and marketing monopolies and lead to seed price increases.
Your petitioners therefore pray that Parliament:
(1) refrains from enacting any legislation on PVR,
(2) calls for a public enquiry into the impact of existing overseas PVR schemes on the Australian seed industry and the international seed trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-

That all members of the Women's Services 1939-45 War qualify as ''Australian Soldier'' under the Defence Service Homes Act for loans because on voluntarily joining the Australian Forces they took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies making themselves available for combat duty in War Zones, and according to Acts and Regulations of the period the Military women had enlisted for service anywhere, some Naval women to sail in any waters, with all servicewomen available for service in Papua New Guinea.

As those members of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force of 1939-45 War who were not sent to War Zones are granted loans, refusal to grant eligibility to all Ex-servicewomen of 1939- 45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you amend the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth- That members of the Women's Services of the 1939-45 War not at present considered eligible for Defence Service Home Loans should qualify as ''Australian Soldiers'' under the Defence Service Homes Act. They volunteered for service with Naval, Military and Air Forces, serving wherever they were sent in whatever capacity they were required and yet are refused Defence Service Home Loans.

They took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies which meant to fight His Majesty's enemies, and although not used in actual combat in war zones, they were available for that use and had a sufficiently grave need arisen would have been used, to serve with distinction as have women of other lands.

In accordance with the Acts and Regulations of the period, the women of the Military Forces had enlisted for service anywhere, some of the Naval women to sail in any waters, others with service on warships optional, while the women of the Air Force could have been sent to Papua New Guinea or other Territories under the control or care of Australia.

Ex-servicemen of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force who volunteered in the 1939-45 War but were not sent to War Zones are granted home loans. Not to grant eligibility to all Ex- servicewomen of 1939-45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you favourably consider amending the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Child Care Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
Taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other business expenses.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Trans Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans-Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans Australia Airlines would inevitably result in:
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans Australia Airlines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australian Parliament assembled.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament assembled take action as it deems appropriate to ensure that the present Federal Government children's services programme is maintained and improved, and the Child Care Act is retained as a legislative base for this important programme.
In considering the recommendations of the Spender report, no recommendations put forward should be implemented without full consultation with community groups.

The present subsidy system to Child Care Centres should be retained. The proposal that monies be made available to subsidize child care in commercial centres is viewed with grave concern. The proposal to alter the present guidelines for subsidy in different programmes and introduce a common means test is also viewed with grave concern, as the present arrangements are effective.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action on the abovementioned issues.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that:
1. The 17.5 per cent tax on pet foods places unreasonable financial strain on pensioners and other pet owners.
2. A pet is not a luxury item for many owners, it fills a vital part in their lives and, in many cases, is therapeutically beneficial, particularly for families and pensioners.

3. The added financial strain may cause many people to abandon or otherwise dispose of their pets, thus adding to the distress of already disadvantaged people and further overloading the resources of animal welfare societies.
4. In view of the abandonment of sales tax on veterinary drugs, it seems inconsistent to tax pet foods when food is as much a basic need as medicines.
We therefore request that this tax on pet food be immediately withdrawn.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Budget imposition of additional sales tax to both existing sales taxed items and to previously exempt goods:
(a) will add to the regressivity of the tax structure by imposing a similar burden on all sections of the community-regardless of the capacity to pay tax;
(b) will be highly inflationary and a disincentive to economic performance in key sectors of manufacturing industry, e.g. car manufacturing; textiles and footwear; boat-building;

(c) is yet another breach of Government promise, given the Treasurer's undertaking in the Parliament on March 12 of this year that there would be no increases in indirect taxation (without at the same time giving personal tax relief).

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to repeal the Budget amendments to sales tax legislation and to withdraw its sales tax amendment bills which add sales tax to presently exempt goods.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Roads Construction Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners believe that:
The decision to subject the National Roads Construction Program to the tendering system will:
(a) threaten the jobs of 790 workers employed in 17 main road depots in New South Wales;
(b) impair the day labour system and undermine the capacity of Departments of Main Roads to train staff and test road construction concepts;
(c) have a disruptive effect on the employment opportunities available in small communities;
(d) reduce the flexibility of the Department of Main Roads to handle emergencies caused by flood or fires;
(e) ultimately increase the cost of road construction at taxpayers' expense.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government withdraw this disruptive proposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Retention of Census Forms
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Commonwealth Government, on the advice of the Bureau of Statistics, has rejected the view that all census forms should be retained, as they are in Britain and the United States. These forms contain much vital information of an historial, medical, and sociological nature which should be available to future generations.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this decision be reconsidered, especially since the view of a majority of the members of the Australian Law Reform Commission was in favour of retaining individual census returns.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Government's Sales Tax legislation imposes an unreasonable burden on the community generally, especially pensioners, families, those in receipt of smaller incomes and small businesses.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw or repeal its Sales Tax Legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of Disabled
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The failure of the Federal Government to seek information from the census re disabled people-that is, partial or total disability-to enable for adequate planning of, and for, types of services needed by disabled people to be undertaken.

2. The failure of the Federal Government to lead the way in employment of disabled people by employing a greater number of such people within the Commonwealth Public Service-note the small number currently employed within the Service.

3. The wastage of the Federal Government funds perpetuating large, bureaucratic institutions and organisations where there are often few disabled people on their boards and little emphasis is placed on consumer participation in decision making.
4. The failure of the Federal Government to encourage independence of disabled people, or to develop 'normalised' support systems-attendance care.
5. The failure of the Federal Government to provide 'noninstitutionalised' specialised accommodation for those people who would not be able to benefit from , or cope with attendant care.
6. Failure by the Federal Government to alter, or create a 'disability' allowance means test free for all disabled people-this would assist with necessary equipment and mobility costs.
7. Failure to provide a national compensation scheme thus saving time and enabling people to be automatically covered in the event of a disability.
8. Failure by the Federal Government to abolish tariffs on all equipment available to the disabled-for example Optaxon.
9. Mismanagement of Federal I.Y.D.P. Funds-for example non-receipt by some States of funds through unresolved negotiations.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that immediate action be taken to remedy the above stated and that the Federal Government recognises that disabled people are citizens who should have equal rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Highway: Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of North Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the National Highway is the responsibility of the Federal Government.
The Bruce Highway in North Queensland is of inferior standard for a National Highway.
Queensland has suffered a 15 per cent disadvantage over other states during the past ten years in road funding.
And the state of the Highway is deteriorating as maintenance expenditure is insufficient to maintain even the present standard.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the parliament will allocate sufficient expenditure, to raise the standard of the national Highway in North Queensland to Department of Transport standards, in conjunction with the Queensland Government, within ten years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions of Italian Immigrants
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament Assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Government take urgent steps to formulate and approve a Social Security Agreement with the Italian Government based on the rights and the needs of Italian immigrant workers in Australia.

Moreover, with the present petition we request that the following important questions related to the pensions of Italian immigrants be urgently resolved within such an agreement; in particular we request:

1. That Italian immigrants who have gained the right to Australian pensions and are no longer resident in Australia be given the opportunity to apply for and obtain the pension without having to return to Australia.
2. That periods of residence in Australia of less than ten years presently required by the Australian legislation be considered for some entitlement to the Australian pension.
3. That the issue concerning the unfair reduction applied to the pension of Australian residents who are receiving an Italian pension be resolved.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Institute of Early Childhood Development
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of Citizens in Victoria showeth:
That at a general meeting concern was expressed as to the necessity to retain the Institute of Early Childhood Development as an autonomous institution.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you would make note of the following resolution passed at a public meeting held in Melbourne on 12 August 1981:

'We request that the Federal Government continue funding the Institute of Early Childhood Development as an autonomous specialist institution recognising that it is unique in its capacity to serve the needs of the early childhood field in Victoria and throughout Australia.'
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, M.P. and the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, M.P.-

(1) That in 1964 a Liberal-Country Party Government granted Mr Anthony, M.P., a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $17,964 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4.75 per cent and that at 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $15,005.

(2) That in 1970 a Liberal-Country Party Government granted Mr Nixon, M.P., a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $30,352 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 6.25 per cent and that at 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $28,404.

(3) Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government immediately extend these most generous terms to the many thousands of young couples in South Australia who are at present suffering undue hardship and financial embarrassment due to high interest rates.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 23 February.
Clause 40 (Documents concerning certain operations of agencies).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now half way through consideration of the Freedom of Information Bill in the Committee of the Whole. The Opposition has been moving a series of amendments to this Bill. If my recollection is right, last evening we finished consideration of our proposed amendment No. 15. I now move amendment No. 16:

SPEECH.PARA: (16) Clause 40, page 27, omit the clause, substitute the following clause: Documents concerning certain operations of agencies '40. A document is an exempt document if its disclosure under this Act-
(a) would, or could reasonably be expected to-
(i) prejudice the effectiveness of procedures or methods for the conduct of tests, examinations or audits by an agency;
(ii) prejudice the attainment of the objects of particular tests, examinations or audits conducted or to be conducted by an agency;
(iii) have a substantial adverse effect on the management or assessment of personnel by the Commonwealth or by an agency; or
(iv) have a substantial adverse effect on the conduct by or on behalf of the Commonwealth or an agency of industrial relations negotiations; and
(b) would be contrary to the public interest.'.

Clause 40 of the Bill relates to documents concerning certain operations of agencies and provides that such documents will be exempt under certain circumstances. Criteria are given. Honourable members will notice that our proposed amendment states much the same thing, that is, that the documents are exempt. However, we seek to add the very important criterion that it is essential that exemption be granted only if the disclosure would be contrary to the public interest. In other words, we include in our proposed amendment relating to internal testing by agencies an overriding public interest test. Our proposed amendment provides that a document is exempt if there is a suggestion that disclosure would cause difficulties by way of procedures or audits, or if there would be an adverse effect on supervision, management policy or industrial relations.

That is fine, but let us talk about the public interest in respect of all those matters. I need not delay the debate too much; I merely say that our proposition is that documents certainly should be exempt if their disclosure would prejudice the effectiveness of procedures or the attainment of objects or would have an adverse effect on management or conduct by or on behalf of the Commonweath or an agency of industrial relations and would be contrary to the public interest. Unless public interest is involved in all those matters we are not helping the real concept of what we are about, that is, strong democracy with information being made available to the people who elect us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept this amendment. Without recapitulating what clause 40 provides, I can explain the background to the Government's decision not to accept the amendment. There is a concern that the inability to protect the confidentiality of documents, such as reports on efficiency reviews and staff utilisation reviews within an agency, would inhibit the full and frank co-operation which is required for those reviews to be conducted effectivley. Paragraph (b) of clause 40 of the Bill would enable the confidentiality of such documents to be protected when it can be shown that their disclosure would or could reasonably be expected to have a substantial adverse effect on review procedures or on achieving acceptance of proposals resulting from those reviews.

SPEECH.PARA: However, a more significant problem could be caused by confining the industrial relations test solely to industrial relations negotiations. In particular instances, in practice there is no distinction between industrial relations policy and matters going to industrial relations negotiations, administration and arbitration. In the common circumstance, when authorities or departments are , like unions, conducting negotiations on the basis of a broad policy or strategy the release of policy or other material most likely would compromise the negotiating stance not only for any talks already in train but also for talks which could arise for some time to come. I think that is a very important point. If parties are conducting such negotiations or are engaged in a matter of industrial relations it would be unfair to provide under this legislation, in the name of freedom of information, the capacity for a party outside government to call for the production of documents which a government agency is relying upon them, from the very nature of things, negotiations or another aspect of the conduct of industrial relations are proceeding. I suppose one might say that there is an element of fairness in that, which in itself is a quality of some importance when trying to judge what is or is not in the public interest.

To add a separate public interest test would place an undue limitation on the exemption which is provided for in the Bill. Clause 40 of the Bill directs attention to the fact that the kinds of harm specified in the clause are themselves contrary to public interest. It is enough that those kinds of harm might reasonably be expected to result from the disclosure of documents to make a document exempt. The argument in this is not unlike the argument I addressed on behalf of the Government when considering amendment No. 15, the last amendment we considered last night.
Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 41 to 43-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move amendments Nos 17 and 18 to clause 43:

SPEECH.PARA: (17) Clause 43, page 28, omit paragraphs (b) and (c) of sub-clause (1), substitute the following word and paragraph:

(2) 'or (b) information (other than trade secrets) concerning a person in respect of his business or professional affairs or concerning the business, commercial or financial affairs of an organisation or undertaking, being information-

(i) the disclosure of which would, or could reasonably be expected to, unreasonably disadvantage that person in respect of his lawful business or professional affairs or that organisation or undertaking in respect of its lawful business, commercial or financial affairs; or

(ii) the disclosure of which under this Act would, or could reasonably be expected to, impair the ability of the Commonwalth or of an agency to obtain information of a similar kind to that contained in the document in the future for the purpose of the administration of matters administered by an agency.'.
(18) Clause 43, page 28, omit sub-clause (3), substitute the following sub- clauses:

'(3) A document is an exempt document if its disclosure under this Act would disclose information (other than trade secrets) concerning the business, commercial or financial affairs of an undertaking that is carried on by, or by an authority of, the Commonwealth, being information the disclosure of which under this Act-
(a) would, or could reasonably be expected to, unreasonably disadvantage that undertaking in respect of its lawful business, commercial or financial affairs; and
(b) would be contrary to the public interest.

'(4) A reference in sub-sections (1) and (2) to an undertaking includes a reference to an undertaking that is carried on by, or by an authority of, a State, the Northern Territory or a local government authority.'.

I deal first with amendment No. 17, which proposes that paragraphs (b) and (c) of clause 43 (1) be omitted. If honourable members look at clause 43 they will see that it deals with documents relating to business affairs, et cetera, and provides that such documents are to be exempt in certain circumstances. Those circumstances are:
(a) trade secrets;-
We have no objection to that-
(b) any other information having a commercial value . . .
(c) Information (other than trade secrets or information to which paragraph (b) applies) concerning a person in respect of his business . . .

That would be information which, if it were disclosed, would be likely to affect adversely that person. If honourable members look at our amendment they will see that what we are saying is that we ought to be able to draft this provision better than it has been drafted. We seek to tidy up this clause by drafting it in the way we have submitted. We consider it redundant to have paragraph (b) relating to commercial value and paragraph (c) using much the same words. We are anxious to protect anybody who might be adversely affected, but we do not want too wide a definition. That appears to be the situation with paragraph (b), relating to any information having a commercial value. That is an extremely wide definition. We want to define what we are about; that is, the adverse effect.

We of the Opposition see no reason why the Commonwealth, State or local government authorities should get such an exemption. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make a couple of general observations while supporting the remarks which have been made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen). I may say that the remarks of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) come strangely from a man who supports an economic policy which is based largely on the alleged merits of the free market and which, we are told all the time, says that competition and the operation of the invisible hand of the market are the best things to regulate the economy. I remind the Minister that the man who is the great father of laissez-faire economics, Adam Smith, one might say a spiritual godfather of this Government, always used to argue that one could not have the free market operating unless one had perfect information, unless all the people who were involved in the transactions-the employers, the employees, a seller and a consumer-were equally based; they had to have the same access to the free market in information.

SPEECH.PARA: I also make the point that in a number of areas of commerce now many so-called trade secrets have a relevance which evaporates so quickly that one begins to wonder what all the fuss is about. In many ways, particularly in the higher technological industries in which I have become increasingly, not to say obsessionally, interested, the rate of change is such that it is not really a matter of finding out what a particular trade secret is. One has to have the actual technology, the skills, the people and so on to bring some new stage of development to a product. I seriously doubt whether there is going to be much practical effect in providing for all these provisions with regard to trade secrecy. It is very interesting that in a number of the new high technology areas-for example, biotechnology and micro-electronics-increasingly the products and the processes are not being patented at all, there is no particular sense of having a specific property right in something. The argument is, in a sense, that if one is physically placed that one can go out and beat one of the market leaders, then good luck, go out and do it. It is not the lack of information that prevents one from beating one of the market leaders. What prevents one from doing it is the fact that one has not got the combination of capital, the technology, the years of experience and the specific skills. Once upon a time it used to be argued that the success or failure of a business could be determined by the fact that one had a whole heap of secrets that were found in a document somewhere and if one passed the document over to someone else the possession of those secrets would suddenly change the relative economic position. I think that is becoming quite an obsolete concept.

I just wanted to draw attention for a moment to the reference about the documents affecting personal privacy. I want to mention a case that occurred in England in the last couple of years which I think indicates that the matter can really cut both ways. I do not know whether the Minister is familiar with the long struggle of Iain Sproat-an unfortunate name, but there it is-Conservative Member of Parliament for Aberdeen South, to secure access to the papers relating to the British humorous writer P. G. Wodehouse. During the Second World War, Wodehouse was captured by the Germans and interned. During that period he made broadcasts which were aimed at an American audience and which, if one reads the text of them, were really quite satirical in nature. Nevertheless, it was said of him that he was a Nazi sympathiser, that he had collaborated and so on. The unfortunate Wodehouse was under a cloud until he received a knighthood in the last year of his life but never returned to England, remaining a virtual exile until his death. In the last years of his life, and for a period after his death , repeated attempts were made, by Mr Sproat in particular, to gain access to his security file.

The argument that was offered repeatedly, during all of the attempts to obtain access to the documents was: 'This is not going to do anybody any good; it cannot help Wodehouse's reputation. It is better to leave it alone. Let him die in peace. The material is so adverse to him that it will make the apprehension about his wartime record even worse.' That was the line taken. But Mr Sproat persisted. Wodehouse said that he had no objection to the documents being made available.

The next stage was to tell Mr Sproat that the documents were also harmful to the reputations of innocent people involved; that it would not do any good; that it would be impossible to disentangle one set of documents from another. Finally , after a struggle which went on for quite some years, Sproat gained access to the Wodehouse file and found that the documents were absolutely innocuous. Moreover, those who had interrogated Wodehouse at the end of the war had said that they were perfectly satisfied with his explanation, that he was an old man and that there were certain limitations upon how people over the age of 60 were to be treated. It was stated that there had been a strong satirical element in his broadcasts, that he had been able to pass on information helpful to other people who were interned and that there was no basis for prosecution-that Woodhouse had come out of the investigation well.

The point is that for some 35 years some panjandrum in a department, for personal reasons had said: 'No, it would not be right to let these documents out .' This is one case where, in a sense, a concern for privacy operated in a way that was quite adverse to the individual. I should add, just to finish the story , that when the documents were to be handed over they contained one ambiguous reference to another living person, embodied in a single sentence. With the techniques available-the use of Xerox machines and so on-that reference was easy to obliterate. Thus, it was possible to hand the entire file over with but a single name and sentence deleted.

What worries me is that in Australia we have an addiction to over-emphasising secrecy procedures. I cannot help remembering an incident which occurred a few years ago when I was a member of the Public Accounts Committee. An inquiry was being conducted concerning the enormous cost of restoration and maintenance of the ablutions block at the Air Force base near Townsville. Whenever the Committee tried to get information about how many toilet seats, shower screens and so on there were, the almost instinctive reaction of the Defence Department was to say: 'That is classified; you cannot have that information. If it fell in the wrong hands who knows what would happen to the nation's security?' We have to be very careful about this over-reliance on secrecy, and someone who is not really accountable in any public way making a decision which offers no contribution to common sense at all.

SPEECH.PARA: (19) Clause 44, page 29, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Documents affecting national economy
'44. A document is an exempt document if its disclosure under this Act-

(a) could reasonably be expected to result in an undue benefit or detriment to any person or class of persons by reason of giving premature knowledge of or concerning proposed or possible action or inaction of the Government or Parliament of the Commonwealth in the course of, or for the purpose of, managing the national economy; and

This amendment seeks to omit existing clause 44 and substitute another. However, let us first consider what the Government proposes. Clause 44 is headed: ' Documents affecting national economy'. Let me say that at the moment the Government must have that document in its possession, because it is not doing very well in the management of the economy. We would be delighted to get hold of it. We might be able to correct some of the tragic circumstances of our citizens. I cannot understand why even criticism can affect the management of the economy. During Question Time, honourable members are berated if they dare mention exchange rates, interest rates or foreign investment. Everything is deemed to be hush hush.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could cover the Budget itself.

—That is right. Everything is so hush hush that it must be left to those who are elected but who, unfortunately, seem to be making such a dreadful mess of the economy. SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's amendment provides certainly a document should be exempt if it could be expected to result in any undue benefit or detriment to a person by reason of giving premature knowledge of any proposal. It would have to be contrary to the public interest. Again this evening we have heard the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) saying that the Government can do it all but does not wish to subject itself to the test of public interest at all. We are all here in the public interest. We were all elected by the public and if, in the course of any determination here, it was established by way of argument that the public interest would be adversely affected, of course any such document would be deemed exempt. Not to be prepared to go to the test really gives exclusive power to the Executive, or to the Government or department concerned, as the case may be. If we are dealing with the economy, that involves the most volatile part of our debate in this Parliament. As my colleague the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) says, the Budget is about the only thing we get a little time to discuss. Unfortunately, nobody takes too much notice of what is said. It is printed before we debate it and because the printer has printed it nobody can ever alter it. What happens in the economy, in the finish, bears no relationship to what is printed. It is an incredible result. For example, the deficit is no longer the deficit we were given; apparently it has bloomed out to hundreds of millions of dollars which obviously will have an adverse effect on the economy. None of us have been able to get hold of any document in relation to this. If we had we might have been able to make a substantial, worthwhile contribution. That is our role.

In regard to this sort of exclusion whereby documents can be exempted because they will affect the economy, or for any reason at all that might have an undue disturbance on the ordinary business of the Community, the mind is unable to grasp what the Government intends, bearing in mind that we are seeking documents that exist. If they exist, somebody has had access to them-that is the point we make-and certainly we ought to be able to talk about, for example, proposals for expenditure, perhaps in relation to foreign investment. Today we had a report from the Foreign Investment Review Board clearly indicating all the details of the investment and all the problems associated with it, giving comments as to how all the local capital in Australia is being absorbed. It is only when we get a document such as that that we can ask questions of the Government.

To say we cannot do it, that we cannot get access to these documents, creates a climate in which the Government always will be preserved from criticism. Certainly that is the case in regard to the people who have to operate the economy. The Government operates very little of the economy; it is the greatest tax gatherer. Other people are out there trying to manage their businesses and get the economy going. They will make profits and pay taxes to the Government. They have a right-from their point of view and understanding-to absorb some of a Government's policy.

This situation does give undue preference to some. Those who are in privileged positions of power know what government's proposals are and certainly they can get the advantage of premature knowledge. We are not casting any doubts on that at the moment but the suggestion that other people could get such information certainly is not likely to be the case. —How would Laurie Oakes go?

The amendment relates to the role of the Ombudsman. We have dealt with Part V of the Bill. We want to insert a completely new Part VA. It is entitled 'Role of the Ombudsman'. We think, as I think everybody in this nation would agree, that there should be a role for the Ombudsman to deal with complaints to the Ombudsman. We believe that there ought to be a special person, a deputy ombudsman, to deal with freedom of information matters. This relates to the fact that there will be reports made by the Ombudsman, there will be investigations by the Ombudsman of action taken by Ministers and the fact that the Ombudsman may represent persons in proceedings before the Tribunal. All that, I think, is very essential and necessary and would be in accord with the spirit of what the role of an ombudsman is these days.

It is important, in the course of administration, that there be an independent arbiter, namely, the Ombudsman, who can not necessarily override ministerial decisions but certainly can review whether those decisions have been properly based. In many cases, of course, the work of the Ombudsman is very fruitful indeed. In fact, it is of some significance and it is certainly beneficial to our modern democracy that there is an opportunity to review what is happening pursuant to the laws that we pass and their administration. It is not much good passing laws and expecting them to be administered the way we thought they would be. In fact, it appears very clear that in a number of areas they can perhaps be misinterpreted. DEBATE.TITLE: CANNED FRUITS MARKETING LEGISLATION REPEAL AND AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 February, on motion by Mr Nixon:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House has a general debate covering the Canned Fruits Marketing Legislation Repeal and Amendment Bill and the Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill as they are associated measures? Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these two measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is opposed to the Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill but is not opposed to the Canned Fruits Marketing Legislation Repeal and Amendment Bill. It has taken the Government about two years to introduce the latter Bill. It should have been done earlier when the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation was set up two years ago. The reason we are opposed to the Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill is the trouble the industry is now in. Now is not the time to impose an extra levy on an industry. Now is not the time to lift the levy from 11c to 27c a basic carton. Now is not the time for the Government to impose this sort of levy on an industry in as much trouble as the canned fruits industry is in. The Government will take over $1m from the industry when growers are going broke.

SPEECH.PARA: It is unacceptable to the Opposition to ask for more money from an industry at a time when that industry is in desperate need of Federal financial assistance. We propose that the extra marketing initiative which is needed should be provided by the Department of Trade and Resources and the Department of Primary Industry when, first of all, the ACFC has demonstrated its ability effectively to manage the marketing of Australian canned fruit and its interest in the industry by preparing an IAC submission for the next hearing scheduled for May next year. The Opposition then will be pleased to review its position of not supporting an increase in the levy for canned deciduous fruit.

I conclude by pointing out what the labor Party Government did for the industry in 1973 when ex-Senator Ken Wriedt was Minister for Primary Industry. In that year the Labor Government provided $1.5m in grants to canners for revaluation assistance. We also gave emergency adjustment assistance to canning fruit growers. That emergency assistance was provided in the form of payments to canning fruit growers and those payments were made on the basis of deliveries of peaches, pears and apricots to canneries for canning in the 1972-73 season. Payments were made at the rate of $12 a tonne on up to 125 tonnes, with a maximum payment of $1,500 to a grower. Also at that time we had a tree pull scheme, which we continued. Funding by the Labor Government to rural reconstruction and rural adjustment was at a high level. The Government has now phased out the tree pull scheme and, on the other measure, funds are being cut back all the time. In 1973 the Labor Government did respond to the needs of the canning fruit industry. The current Government's response to a canning fruit crisis is to raise the levy which funds the Australian Canned Fruit Corporation.

If we look at the income received from the industry over the past three or four years we see that it amounted to $587,000 in 1979 when we had the Australian Canned Fruits Board; it amounted to $720,000 in 1980 when the Corporation was formed, representing an increase of 23 per cent; and in 1981 the Corporation gained $800,000 from the industry, representing an increase of 11 per cent. Now the Government is proposing that the levy go up to give the Corporation an income of an estimated $1,080,000, representing an increase of 35 per cent. That is to happen in a year when the intake of fruit is down by up to 38 per cent-the quotas are down by that amount-and in a year when the price for the fruit has dropped to disastrous levels. The price for pears has dropped $30 a tonne and the price for peaches has dropped $45 a tonne. What the Government is doing is attacking another primary industry which has experienced serious economic downturn, as has been demonstrated, and which faces another period of reconstruction due to the policies of the European Economic Community. The Opposition wants to help those members of this House who represent some of the seats in which canning fruit is grown. Surely the honourable members for Murray (Mr Lloyd), Wakefield (Mr Giles) and Riverina (Mr Hicks) have been putting pressure on the Government not to impose this levy at this time.
Let me refer to some of the quotes in the Press of recent days. For example, Mr Philip Marshall, the Secretary of the Australian Canning Fruitgrowers Association, was reported as follows:
. . . the reductions in prices only added more weight to the argument that the industry urgently needed help.
Peaches have been set at $180 a tonne, a reduction of $45 a tonne on last year' s price while pears have been set at $130 a tonne, $30 less than 1981.
. . . it is now abundantly clear that the canned fruit industry in the Goulburn -Murray Valley of Victoria will have to rely heavily on the Victorian Government for assistance.

Producers and industry representatives in the various States are now appealing to their State governments. For example, on 2 February Mr Sam Catanzariti, the New South Wales President of the Canning Fruitgrowers Association, said:
As far as the growers are concerned, it is disastrous.

I can read other quotes, such as 'SA may go solo on fruit finance'. Mr Chapman, the Minister of Agriculture in that State, again criticised the Commonwealth's refusal to match dollar for dollar the State Government's plan to help this industry. Producers are furious about the drop in price, they are furious about the quotas being cut and they are furious about this Government not taking any action to assist the canning fruit industry. The approach of the Government to this industry has been and is abysmal. The industry has had a long history. The present situation could have easily been anticipated. If I may go back, the previous Minister for Primary Industry, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), the present Minister for Communications, was given a hostile reception at Berri in South Australia, so he knew all about the problems in the industry. For most of his stewardship of the portfolio all we ever heard were some unsympathetic platitudes about the possibility of a private enterprise solution for the canning industry. What he was really talking about was the canners themselves.

The Government wound down the treepull scheme, continued to withdraw funds from the rural adjustment scheme and, of course, ignored most of the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission inquiry that looked at all the fruit industries in the 1970s. It ignored the plan for the Regional Development Authority to help an area such as the Riverland. I am sure the honourable member for Wakefield is fully aware of the problems which that area faces and his colleagues in his own party in South Australia face and of the case they have been making to this Government. But this Government will do nothing. It has done nothing for the fruit growers. It is absolutely essential now that the provisions of the rural adjustment scheme be directed specifically to the needs of growers in this coming season. Unfortunately, because of the way that scheme works, it will probably take eight months to get any money through and by that time the growers will have gone broke.

I think we have to say at this juncture that the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation itself has not performed well in terms of its market judgment or in the administration of its role and functions. Frankly, too much fruit was taken in in the 1981 season. The canneries will lose at least $2.3m for the 1981 season and the situation now is that the fruit growers will have to carry the can for the canners. The quotas are being cut. The growers will not get anywhere near the same amount of money and they will not be allowed to produce the same quantity of fruit. In other words, the fruit growers are going to amortise the losses of the fruit canners. Harking back to the free enterprise solution of the former Minister for Primary Industry, the only private enterprise firm, Henry Jones of Kyabram, has got out with its quotas being sold to SPC and Ardmona with the compliance of the Corporation. All canners are now co-operatives. Letona is in receivership and the Riverland Canning Co-operative is bankrupt and is in debt. Some calculations there go as high as $28m.

At the Australian Agricultural Council meeting on 8 February this year the South Australian and New South Wales Ministers for Agriculture severely criticised the Federal Government and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) in particular for the Government's failure to assist the canning fruit industry. The Victorian Government also indicated that it would request Federal assistance for its canning fruit growers. The only response from the Minister for Primary Industry was that there would be no action until after the IAC had presented its interim report. It is not due until 31 March this year when the fruit under discussion will be well and truly finished. Either it will have been picked or it will be on the ground, and most of it will be on the ground. The Letona cannery in New South Wales has debts of $14m to State Government authorities and $5m to the State Government, but only $875,000 to the Commonwealth Government. During 1981 the New South Wales Government, a Labor government, under the responsible Minister, Jack Hallam, put $1.7m into canning fruit loans. The South Australian Government, a Liberal government, has provided $560,000 to canning fruit growers, half of which is to be used to supplement grower returns on fruit delivered to canneries and half of which is to provide loans to growers. The Victorian Government is trying to develop some sort of plan to assist its own growers. We need to point out that, as I am sure the honourable member for Murray will tell the House, some 80 per cent of the canning fruit in this country is produced in Victoria, most of it in his electorate.

The 150 per cent increase in levy that this Government is scandalously putting on the industry is based on the reduction of the production for 1982, down to about 38 per cent of last year's production. Because the Corporation cannot market current production it requires a higher rate of levy on the production it can market. I suppose one could be fooled into thinking it is a reverse economies of scale argument, that because production is lower the costs per unit of production increase. However, that is nonsense. The current position has been reached to a large extent because of the Corporation's apparent ignorance of the marketing situation it was facing. Now growers are being asked to increase their support for an organisation which has not been able to meet the needs of the industry it is responsible for. The Corporation is not being asked to compensate growers for their management. Growers are being asked to compensate the Corporation and give it the funds to continue. No one is questioning the fact that the Corporation should continue, but the Corporation is open to rather stringent criticism. Which other organisation can fail to do its job and then be supported by this Government in asking for a 35 per cent increase in income from people who cannot afford it? It will be guaranteed income as well. I guess this falls in with some of the nonsense that we hear coming from this Government. On Monday the Minister for Primary Industry put the seal of approval on the sale of one Government organisation which made money for primary producers, the Australian Wool Testing Authority. Today he wants to guarantee an increased income for an inept corporation.

Let us look at some of the marketing and management record of the Corporation. What we have is a desperate situation because there is a carry-over of some four million basic cartons. In the previous year there was a carry-over of 1.9 million cartons. It was a high production year but now the growers' intake will be reduced by half and the Fruit Industry Sugar Concession Committee prices have been reduced from the previous year. At the 1981 Outlook Conference the Bureau of Agricultural Economics forecast that on the market prospects sales would drop . Looking back with hindsight, the forecasts of the BAE were quite accurate given the situation at that time. In contrast page 4 of the first annual report of the Corporation, looking towards 1981, states:

Overall the outlook for canning peaches, pears and apricots in 1981 is difficult but not alarming . . . Total sales in 1981 are expected to be around the level of recent years. However, to attain this a considerable effort will be required by the Corporation and its marketers.
I will return to that phrase 'considerable effort'. The BAE 1981 forecast at the Outlook Conference states:
The decline from the 1980 intake is due to relatively less favourable prospects and anticipated high stock levels at the beginning of the canning year.

If that sort of information was available to the BAE why was it not available to the Canned Fruits Corporation? If it was not directly available to the Corporation-its representatives were at the Outlook Conference-it could have discussed the forecasts. There was a failure, or there was ignorance of what the situation was.

I turn to the matter of 'considerable effort'. In the first annual report, the Canned Fruit Corporation talked of, among other things, the decline in the United Kingdom market, our major customer, the expanding Middle East market, ACFC promotions, visits overseas by members of the Corporation and EEC support for local canned fruit production. It also set out the function of the Corporation and the major expenditure, $640,000-60 per cent of the budget-in promotions overseas. Knowing the way in which the United Kingdom market was going in the past decade-to use their own words-and that the Middle East had been an expanding market, what the Corporation did during 1980 was send seven people at different times to Europe, mainly West Germany and Italy, to talk about pears. They also looked at canned fruit production in Spain and Greece. No interest was taken in expanding markets in the Middle East, or anywhere except in the traditional places which it always visited. The following was stated:
The largest campaign for canned fruit was again mounted in the United Kingdom.

What happened? In 1980 there were sales of 1,089,000 basic cartons in the United Kingdom, or nearly 200,000 basic cartons below the figure for the preceding year . The major sales promotion for the whole year of the Canned Fruits Corporation managed to achieve a 16 per cent reduction in sales. Now the growers, through the canneries, are being asked by this Government to pay this organisation 150 per cent more. On page 11 of the report, the Corporation said:

In 1980 the only export area where the Australian industry experienced increased sales was General Export markets . . . an advance of 20 per cent was reflected . . . Middle East countries have continued to evidence a strong growth rate over the last decade.
Yet no mention is made of any visit by Corporation members to the only bright spot referred to in their whole annual report.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which points out how the market in the Middle East is growing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Surely a visit to Saudi Arabia would have been worthwhile. That country took more than 60 per cent of our exports to the Middle East in 1980-81. It is a large and growing proportion of our total exports but, during that year, I understand that corporation members visited Hamburg. At the recent annual meeting of the Canning Fruitgrowers this visit was put forward by the Corporation as a highlight of the Corporation's activities for the year. Therefore, it appears that the Corporation's market development and promotion activities have not changed. It is equally difficult to know how the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) who is responsible for this organisation, can support the case for a 150 per cent increase in levy when the Corporation's performance is as I have described.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the matter of quotas. The ACFC administers production quotas and pool markets for the more profitable export markets. Canners can transfer entitlements. These production quotas on canneries are intended to discourage over-production. Production in excess of entitlement is the responsibility of the canner. What I understand has happened is that the Corporation last year simply raised the quota levels when it found that there was a lot of fruit.

The ACFC, as I have mentioned, also approved the sale of quotas from Henry Jones, of Kyabram, to the two other Victorian canners. Henry Jones was paid for the quotas but suppliers to its factories were left with no guarantee of any outlet for fruit beyond this 1982 harvest. Already growers in the Shepparton area have been coming to me about this. One fellow said that he had paid $10,000 for delivery rights to Henry Jones when he bought his fruit block but, a month later, Henry Jones having been sold, he had no rights and did not know where he was. To get it down to the personal level, there are even people in my electorate of Werriwa who have gone broke in fruit farming and come to me about it. So, quite a few people are concerned to know a good deal about the state in which the industry finds itself. The situation they face in the coming year is very serious indeed.

I propose now to touch briefly on the Bill to which we do not object but concerning which we would make the comment that the Government has encouraged growers for the last two years to fund two organisations when only one was required. The other was the Sales Promotion Committee. At a time when market prospects were grim and fruit growers on small mixed blocks could ill afford to fund one organisation, let alone two, growers had no choice because of the legislation which demanded levys. I will provide proof of that. The functions of the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation are set out as:
. . . to undertake responsibilities for the regulation, marketing and promotion of canned deciduous fruits in Australia and overseas.
The functions of the Australian Canned Fruit Sales Promotion Committee are:
. . . to promote the sale within Australia or overseas of canned fruit.

This is another example of the lack of interest by this Government and the tardiness with which this Minister acts in allowing this duplication to continue . Certainly we support the moves taken by the Minister to repeal that and put all sales promotion in the hands of the Corporation.

If we look now at the industry in more general terms we note that it was rationalised to a very large degree in the 1970s. That is a nice economic euphemism for people getting out of the industry. It now faces the major crisis to which I have referred, due to a reduction in sales volume and prices in export markets. The main reason, in addition to what I have outlined, is the intense competition from the highly subsidised production within the EEC and South Africa, as well as the upturn in the value of the Australian dollar since January 1981. Again, this is a policy that the Government has deliberately followed under its fighting inflation first strategy. It is using the exchange rate as a tool against inflation and, in so doing, is harming our rural export industry.

I turn to the figures that have caused these decisions by the Corporation which are affecting this industry so badly. Total sales volume for 1981 will be about 5.9 million cartons, against an availability of some 9.9 million cartons. This gives a carry-over of 4 million cartons compared with the previous year's figure of 1.9 million. In the years prior to 1980, sales were about 7 million cartons per annum. In 1980, they fell to 6.6 million and in 1981 to 5.9 million, as I have said, it is calculated that a desirable carry-over would be about 1.5 million cartons. Given that carry-over, it has been decided by the Corporation that the canners will take only 3.8 million basic cartons of fruit this year, virtually halving the production available. Sales are expected of about 6.12 million cartons; so, stock levels should be reduced. It should not be necessary to cut intake so severely in future years. In some ways, this year's plan will be a sudden, sharp shock followed by reduced levels of the usual intake in the years to come. It is simply a sharp shock that the industry will find very hard to accept. But, if we add to that the fact that the Government is going to try to get an extra $280,000 out of the industry, the position is scandalous.

So that the Corporation can carry on its work, the Government has decided to more than double the levy on the growers. It is up by more than 150 per cent. As I have said, the growers are being asked to carry the can for the canners. They are to be asked to pay when they can least afford to do so. The Government has no intention of doing anything about the industry. Of course the Minister will take refuge in the excuse, as he did at the Australian Agricultural Council meeting when the governments of Victoria, New South Wales and South Australia made a strong case for their growers, that he has referred the matter to the Industries Assistance Commission. So he has, but I wish to refer to what has happened at the IAC.

One would expect that, when an industry is in so much trouble and the IAC is asked to report on short term assistance with three months, all organisations involved would want to offer their best advice, especially the organisation charged with the ultimate marketing and management of that commodity, that is, if market downturns and supply management seem to be the major problems. In December 1981, the IAC was asked to report on short term assistance for the 1982 season. Hearings were set down for 19 January 1982 in Shepparton. Almost everyone who had heard of canned fruit gave evidence except the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation and the canners. It is almost unheard of for a statutory corporation not to present a submission to an IAC inquiry into its industry. I do not know why the ACFE chose not to appear before the IAC but I know that it reflects badly on the Corporation's performance and ability when it is in serious question. This Government is to ask growers to pay 150 per cent more for the services of the ACFC. It is asking this House to support an increase of 150 per cent to a corporation which will not even present itself to the IAC and provide information to assist in its deliberations.
Debate interrupted.
