TALK.START.PARA: —I have been long concerned about the Australian Broadcasting Commission and its role in Wollongong, which is in my electorate. My concern has turned to alarm in the light of the consistent attacks made by this Government, as explained in an internal memo circulated to ABC staff dated 15 February 1982 from the General Manager, Sir Talbot Duckmanton. This document is of such interest to the Parliament that I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
15 February 1982
EXPENDITURE AND STAFFING RESTRAINTS 1981-82

When the ABC's appropriation for the 1981-82 financial year was determined, it was understood that further funds would be provided at Additional Estimates time for approved salary and wage increases which had occurred during the course of the financial year, but that additional funds for non-salary wage increases, i.e . for increases in the cost of goods and services, would not normally be provided.

In January, 1982, however, the Government, as part of its policy of expenditure restraint, decided that steps should be taken by Government Departments and Statutory Authorities to restrain, until finalisation of the 1981-82 Additional Estimates, certain expenditures and, in particular, to absorb the cost of wage and salary increases, as well as increases in other costs. Following our receipt of this advice on 22 January, a detailed examination of our commitments for the balance of the financial year and the extent to which a reduction in expenditure could take place in respect of those funds which had not been committed at that stage, revealed that it was not possible for the ABC to absorb the wage and salary increases which had occurred since 1 July, 1981. In fact, this examination revealed that action which could be taken at that stage would make it possible to absorb only a small part of the cost of these increases. This position was put to the Department of Finance in discussions which took place towards the end of January and, while that Department appreciated that full absorption by the ABC of wage and salary increases was not possible, it stressed that every effort had to be made to reduce expenditure during the remainder of the current financial year.

The Government's policy of expenditure restraint has been further stressed in a telex issued to us by the Department of Communication on 12 February last, advising of a Government decision that, until further notice:
Discretionary expenditure and expenditure which might be flexible with regard to timing, is to be deferred.
Contractual commitments in respect of major equipment acquisitions or other projected expenditure, shall not be entered into.
Wage and salary increases are to be absorbed to the maximum extent possible by eliminating overtime.

It is not possible, of course, for the ABC to cease its equipment acquisition program with respect to its role as Host Broadcaster for this year's Commonwealth Games in Brisbane. Also, if overtime were totally eliminated, there would be a major cutback in program production and transmission. This recent advice from the Department of Communications provides for exemption from these requirements to be sought in areas of 'special sensitivity' and we will be seeking such exemption where appropriate.

In addition to these expenditure restraints, we have been notified of the need to reduce staff levels below those achieved at 30 June, 1981. In April, 1981, we were advised that the full-time operative staff ceiling was to be cut this financial year by 2%, i.e. a reduction from 6202 to 6072. We lodged an appeal against this provisional reduction in our ceiling, and we have now been advised that following consideration of our appeal, a lesser reduction is to be applied and the full-time operative staff ceiling to be achieved by 30 June next is now 6143, representing a 1% reduction on the number employed at 30 June last.
Therefore, during the remainder of this financial year, we are faced with the need to reduce our full-time operative staff strength to 6143 and, in addition, to reduce expenditure wherever possible.

At its meeting on 12 February, the Commission agreed to express its concern to the Minister at the effect of these restraints on our service and discussed at some length the action which would be necessary to achieve these staffing and expenditure reductions. It was agreed that it was no longer possible for such savings to be achieved through a general sharing of the burden across the board. The Commission recognised that across the board cuts in recent years had reduced the staffing and funds for most activities to a point where they would no longer be viable if further reductions were made, and it therefore decided that the reductions which are now being required of the ABC are to be achieved by identifiable cuts in program activities.

The areas in which these cuts will be made will be considered by the Commission at its March meeting. We have both a short-term and a long-term problem. It will be some months before the savings which will flow from the cuts determined by the Commission will become fully effective and therefore, some short-term measures will have to be taken immediately to achieve the expenditure and staffing reductions required of us in this financial year. The short-term action which the Commission has decided to take includes:
A reduction of $1 million in the capital budget by deferring until 1982/83 any further contractual commitments.

Savings of some $700 000 in the operational budget through, for example, a reduction in both general and engineering training; a general cutback in all areas of Radio Australia; a reduction in the program purchases, publicity, FM and program recordings budgets in the Radio Division; a reduction of output of television drama and in documentary and feature film activities.
A general restraint in expenditure, particularly in overtime and travel.

The staff reductions which will be achieved as a result of the above measures will be less than the 1% cut in our ceiling and the balance is to be achieved through a general restriction in recruitment over the remainder of this financial year.

As indicated above, it is not expected that these short-term measures will continue into the 1982/83 financial year. They are of an interim nature only, pending realisation of savings which will flow from the longer term decisions which the Commission will be taking at its March meeting.
T. S. DUCKMANTON

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. This memo acts on strong directions from this Government to place severe financial constraints on the ABC which will lead inevitably to further chronic underservicing. Such attacks are nothing new from this Government because since gaining office it has been remarkably consistent in attempting to downgrade the ABC and all it stands for; that is, independent and balanced news reporting which has made it famous throughout Australia and Asia, providing alternative entertainment to that offered by commercial radio and television stations too and in general catering to the needs of a community rather than the profit motives of a private corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Duckmanton memo is a recipe for savage curtailment, requiring the ABC internally to absorb wage rises and other cost increases. It demands reductions in program activities, cutting capital costs by $1m and operating costs by $700, 000, including reducing the output of television drama and features and eroding staff conditions including the cutting of overtime and travel. Staff levels are to be reduced to below the level of June 1981; that is, to 6,143-a one per cent reduction. Originally this was to be cut by two per cent and was only modified to one per cent after an appeal by the ABC. The ABC has been cut almost to the bone and this latest savage chopping of programs and staff will leave a skeleton service.

The situation in Wollongong is a disgrace. Wollongong, the seventh largest city in Australia, has a ridiculous pocket-sized ABC. It is laughable to assume that the ABC can cater adequately for the region when the staff comprises two journalists, one casual news typist, two casual announcers and one casual programs officer. That is the sum total of the ABC office in Australia's seventh largest city. Radio station 2WN broadcasts only five hours a day, seven days a week with an additional four hours on Saturday. I am wary of making comparisons with other regions but I must point out that the Newcastle office has one manager, one assistant manager, one staff announcer, six journalists, three office personnel, two casual announcers and a record librarian. Understand- ably , it broadcasts a minimum of 16 hours a day.

In Wollongong, the office is already so downgraded that any further moves to squeeze out so-called cost excesses will be ineffectual. It has already been wrung dry. For instance, a ridiculous situation developed last month as a result of an earlier so-called cost cutting measure when local radio programs on fishing, gardening and bowls, which for years had catered to a regular audience, were dumped, I do not presume to be a program manager but feeling in the community was running high because of the suddenness of the move and the rudeness with which the local comperes were treated. This is no reflection on the local ABC but on the head office.

The ABC Wollongong television service deserves a special mention. It is run, again through no fault of the local ABC, like a Keystone Cops operation. There is no camera crew, let alone any studio facilities. A freelance cameraman is called in when necessary but the evening news film must be rushed onto the train to Sydney before lunch. As honourable members can imagine, the competition with the one commercial station which has a late afternoon deadline, a range of journalists, camera crew and full studio facilities, is not severe.

Wollongong is a huge and complex city catering for a vast range of people-from the steelworks, which is the largest single industrial employer in Australia, to the education complex which includes three technical colleges, an institute of education and a university. It covers the tourist belt known as the Leisure Coast, the rural Southern Highlands and south coast agricultural industry, the southern coalfields, and the urban sector ranging from heavy industry to the assorted manufacturing, retail and services sectors.

It is urgent that the Wollongong ABC office be upgraded, the number of journalists expanded, extra announcers provided and more local radio time permitted. There should also be provision for at least one camera crew for the television news service and arrangements made to convey film to Sydney to an afternoon deadline. If this Government will not implement those reforms, the next Labor Government will. I give that as a pledge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday morning I asked the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) a question. It was on an important issue; it dealt with an important matter. It is unfortunate that what followed smothered the issue I sought to raise. At the centre of the issue are two royal commissions currently proceeding in Victoria, the first into the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the second into the activities of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation. TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I would like to acquaint members of this House with the way in which Government policies on welfare assistance are forcing a pensioner constituent of mine to sell her home because she earns 27c a week too much. The Government policies referred to relate to the unrealistic income limits placed on other income in determining the age pension and the non- indexation of taxation which is forcing people into higher taxation brackets. —Miss Louise Potter of Revesby, who is 76 years of age, wrote to me recently telling me of her plight. Miss Potter's life has been one of support, service to her country, pain and struggle. Being the youngest of a large family she supported her aged parents until her early forties. She served for four years in the Women's Australian Auxiliary Air Force during World War II during which time she sustained a spinal injury. The injury, which seriously disrupted her social and work life, has caused her much pain throughout her entire life. After leaving the Air Force, Miss Potter struggled for several years to convince a bank to give a home loan to a single middle-aged woman. She struggled to pay off that loan and to buy the basic necessities to live. Now at the age of 76, Miss Potter is faced with the predicament that she may have to sell her home.

SPEECH.PARA: Miss Potter, who constantly requires treatment for her spinal injury, is on an 80 per cent disability pension from the Department of Veterans' Affairs. She also gets a part age pension from the Department of Social Security. She has no significant other income. Last November, following the automatic pension rise in line with the consumer price index increase, Miss Potter received notice from the Department of Social Security that she was now 27c over the limit at which she qualified for fringe benefits. This occurred because of two government decisions: Firstly, to count the full disability pension as other income when calculating her social security pension entitlements; and, secondly, not to increase the $20 permissible income for pensioners since 1972-this despite 175 per cent inflation since that time. Pensioners can still earn only up to $20 a week without losing part of their pension.

Both Miss Potter's age pension and disability pension are indexed so that when her disability pension was increased by about $1.50 in November 1981 to make a total of $40.27 a week she no longer qualified for fringe benefits and her age pension was reduced by 75c. She immediately asked the Department of Veterans' Affairs not to give her the increase but it could not do so. For this minor increase Miss Potter now finds herself in a position where she must take out health insurance, pay full council rates and becomes ineligible for other pensioner concessions. As a consequence of her disability, Miss Potter uses an enormous amount of electric power for heating. Her power bill for the last three quarters was $445. Without a pensioner discount, these bills pose a great hardship. All of this will cost her approximately $20 a week extra, something which Miss Potter cannot afford. As she explained to me, the costs of maintaining her home have escalated dramatically over recent years. Yet when she gets any increase in her pension to keep up with price rises, half of that increase is taken away by the Department of Social Security and, with the abolition of tax indexation, a third of the remainder is taken away by taxation. Clearly, Miss Potter's standard of living is rapidly declining and she has now reached the point where she can no longer make ends meet.
The effect of this predicament on Miss Potter is heart-rending. I quote from her letter:

Please excuse this scrawl but the shock of losing my fringe benefits and perhaps being forced to sell my house has made me very ill and left me very shaky. I can scarcely hold the pen. Please excuse, too, this lengthy letter, but just being able to write to someone, instead of thinking and worrying has helped to settle me.
She continued:
I am fairly sure that if the Government realised just what they have done and are doing to us, they would be humane enough to save us this strife.

I wrote to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) on 17 February seeking an increase in Miss Potter's disability pension which I see as the only immediate solution to her financial plight. I implore the Minister to be humane and sympathetic to Miss Potter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to take a few minutes of the time of the House tonight to raise an issue concerning my electorate of McMillan, which I suppose, when we get out the facts, will show just what this Government is capable of doing. Last year a new post office was opened in my electorate in the city of Moe, which meant that we had a vacant block of land because of the new post office being built. With a vacant block of land in Moe and land zoned as public land, the council was very keen to see that something was done with that land which would help the community. So in the normal procedures, the State Government was given the opportunity to see whether it wanted to buy that land. It did not want to do so. Then the council made clear to the Government that it was prepared to buy that land and develop it to see whether it could attract regional government facilities to the La Trobe Valley area. The council made an offer for this block of land of $10,500, based on the fact that the land was zoned public land. That was back in August-September of last year. Communication was conveyed to the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman), and on 7 December I received a letter from him saying that negotiations on the purchase of the site were in progress and he would advise me of the outcome.

SPEECH.PARA: It has come to my attention just in the last 24 hours that the council recently received a letter from this Government, through the Department of Administrative Services, not only rejecting the council's offer for the land but claiming a valuation figure which was obviously calculated as though the land were zoned for commercial purposes. The land is clearly zoned for public purposes and the council has no intention of rezoning that land. The Department also had not acceded to the council's request for a period of 12 months before considering offering the land to the public to enable the council to press its case for the establishment of government offices on that land. The Department has said to the council that it will now hold the property only until 13 March and that no extension will be granted beyond that date. I have taken this matter up with the Minister in seeking an extension of that date to see whether we can get things back on the rails.

But what really concerns me about this matter is as follows: The council was astounded to hear that this Government, through the Department, wrote to the State Department of Planning to seek assistance in determining the zoning which would be applied to the property when it passes to the Commonwealth ownership. In other words, in respect of the land which is zoned by the city as public land and is available for purchase and for which a genuine purchase price has been put forward by the council, the Government has written a letter to the Victorian Liberal State Department of Planning asking for assistance in determining the zoning which would apply to the property when it passes to the Commonwealth ownership. No doubt the council was very upset. It immediately wrote to the Minister for Planning objecting strongly to this line of action and to any changes in the zoning from public purposes reserves.

What sort of a government have we here which takes this sort of approach to public land in a city against the council's wishes? It is fair enough if the Government decides that it can get a little more for that land if it can have it rezoned 'commercial', but surely to goodness, the Commonwealth of Australia has not become so destitute under this Government that it has to go behind the back of a council and write a letter seeking to have this public land rezoned ' commercial'. The council has urged me to take up this matter at the highest possible level. I have raised it tonight because I see this Parliament as the highest possible level to which one can bring such a matter for the attention of the Parliament and the people. I urge members on the Government side to see, when this matter is raised in Cabinet, if it is raised, that their departments do not take this type of approach. If there is a commonsense approach on the part of a local council in a fast developing area to go ahead and develop office space to attract Commonwealth departments to that area so that local people can deal with Australian Taxation Office personnel, for example, and others it should be encouraged to do so.

The Government's actions in this area are totally reprehensible and I urge the Government quickly to reassess the situation and see that the local council is given the 12 months that it wants to see whether it can establish these offices in that area, because it is something that we badly need in the fast growing area of the La Trobe Valley. The Government should withdraw quickly its approach to the State Department of Planning seeking to overrule the council zoning.

QUESTION.PARA: Will he, having regard to my having been requested by the family of the late Terence Ronald Scott to obtain details, provide me with a full statement, giving all relevant dates of Australian and overseas service from enlistment to discharge, and including all medical care sought and either denied or received from military medical personnel, for Terence Ronald Scott, Regimental Number 38649, date of birth 14 July 1947; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
